        "0320": {
            "matches": 2,
            "pathToPage": ".\\_data\\b\\be\\BellHow2016\\pages//0320.html",
            "result": " \n\nGreat Pretenders: Elevations of ‘Good’ Usurpers in Roman Historiography 319\n\ndo so could be interpreted as shamefully avoiding one’s responsibilities. Julian, in\ncontrast, had to put great stress on his recusatio because he did not set out to free\nthe Empire from a tyrant, but saw himself at odds with his own auctor imperii,\nwhich made it problematical to claim that he came to the people’s rescue.\n\nBoth in literature and in practice, acclamations and refusals of the purple\nserved to transfer the responsibility for a candidate’s rise to power from himself to\nthose who supported him, signalling the consent of men and, by implication, the\ngods as well. Through accounts of favourable omens and prophecies (recorded for\nall successful pretenders discussed in this article), the approval of the latter could\nbe made explicit. If all the relevant groups gave their consent freely and uncondi-\ntionally — that is, if they were not bribed, intimidated or deceived — the candidate\nin question could be interpreted as a ‘good’ pretender who rendered his own\nwishes subservient to the interests of the res publica. Only under those conditions\nwas it justified to engage in civil war and seize the throne by force.\n\nSignificantly, the legal foundation of the powers claimed by emperors and\nusurpers — what we might term their formal legitimacy — does not appear to have\nbeen of great concern to our sources. Authors from the principate did not favour\none claimant to the throne over another merely because he happened to possess\nthe imperium proconsulare, the tribuniciae potestas, and all the other titles an\nmandates that formally granted a man imperial power. Evidently, they saw no\npoint in attributing moral value to honours and titles that could be seized by any\ntyrant. In Late Antiquity, the proper performance of the investiture ritual, with the\nuse of the proper attributes, did play a prominent role in the evaluation of imperial\ncandidates, but it was not the only factor of importance. As we have seen, Am-\nmianus did not condemn Julian for his (passive) participation in a highly irregular\ninvestiture ceremony, but presented him as a worthy candidate because he ha\nbeen put forward by others, rather than claiming the purple himself, and because\nhe enjoyed the blessing of the gods. These were the same arguments that earlier\nauthors had already formulated in favour of Vespasian’s usurpation. Imperial le-\ngitimacy, in short, was and remained a fluid concept — and therefore a very usefu\nliterary tool for the creation of great pretenders.\n\n \n\n \n\n \n\nBIBLIOGRAPHY\n\nALFOLDI, A., 1970.             "result": "RITUALE ALS MEDIEN POLITISCHER AUSHANDLUNGEN\nIN DEN BURGERKRIEGEN DER SPATANTIKE\n\nMarco Mattheis\n\nABSTRACT: Both in Constantinople and in the provincial cities, rituals served as a medium of\ncommunication between the monarch and his subjects. Modern scholars often regard them as\nan instrument to legitimise imperial power. However, such a top-down approach ignores the\ndynamics and strategic dimension of rituals. Far from being an exclusive instrument of the\nemperor, rituals were used by many different groups at different levels and with different\naims. They were not only used by, but also against, the emperor. As an example, this article\nexamines the adoration of the imperial images. In Late Antiquity these were sent out to the\ncities of the empire to be welcomed by the provincial population. Usurpers appropriated this\nritual in order to articulate their claim to the throne. The logic behind this strategy was the\nsemantics of consensus the ritual conveyed. Despite their seemingly absolute power the late-\nantique emperors still had to display the consent and acceptance of their subjects in order to\nbe considered legitimate. By appropriating the dispatch of their portraits usurpers tried to call\nupon these semantics and prove their legitimacy to the imperial throne. Imperial rituals were\nmaterialisations of consensus. Paradoxically, this very quality made them powerful instru-\nments of conflict in the late-antique civil wars.\n\nIm zehnten Jahrhundert nach Christus schrieb Kaiser Konstantin VII. Porphyro-\ngennetos ein Traktat tiber die Rituale am Hofe von Konstantinopel.' In seinem\nVorwort begriindete er die Wahl seines Sujets folgendermafen:\n\nManchen, die sich nicht viele Gedanken tiber das Notwendige machen, wiirde mein Vorhaben\nwohl iiberfliissig vorkommen, uns aber scheint es gut, wohlgeraten und sinnvoiler als alles\nandere zu sein, da durch die lobenswiirdige Ordnung die kaiserliche Herrschaft wohlgeordne-\nter erscheint, in ihrem Ansehen zunimmt und dadurch sowohl flir Fremde als auch fiir unsere\nUntertanen bewundernswert ist.”\n\n \n\nMit der lobenswiirdigen Ordnung (ématvet) 141g) bezeichnet Porphyrogennetos\ndie vielfaltigen Rituale am Hof der Hauptstadt, durch die die kaiserliche Herr-\n\ni Zu den methodischen Schwierigkeiten bei der Analyse des Zeremonienbuches: MCCORMICK\n1985.\n\n2 Const.             "result": " \n\nRituale als Medien politischer Aushandlungen in den Biirgerkriegen der Spitantike 369\n\nQuellen explizit hervorgehoben wird. Auch weitere Rituale wie unblutige Opfer,\nKaiserfeste, Hymnen, Adventus und Vota Publica waren von zentraler Bedeutung\nfiir die kaiserliche Herrschaft und wurden daher auch in der Spatantike trotz teils\nerheblicher christlicher Kritik fortgefiihrt.\n\nVor diesem Hintergrund kann es nicht verwundern, dass kaiserliche Rituale in\nder Forschung haufig in einer Top-Down-Perspektive als Herrschaftsmedien ver-\nstanden werden, durch die — ganz besonders seit der Etablierung fester Residenz-\nstadte im frihen 5. Jh. — die kaiserliche Macht in den Provinzen durch ein Netz\nsymbolischer Kommunikation gefestigt wurde. In jiingerer Zeit haben einige\nForscher jedoch daftir pladiert, Rituale nicht mehr als bloBe Machtmittel zu ver-\nstehen, sondern viel starker ihre Polyvalenz, Dynamik und strategische Einsetz-\nbarkeit in den Blick zu nehmen sowie zu zeigen, dass kein Akteur eine dauerhafte\nHandlungsmacht tiber sie ausiiben konnte.'5 Unter einem solchen Blickwinkel\nzeigt sich, dass Rituale vielfach nicht als Medien des Konsenses, sondern auf\nzahlreichen Ebenen als Medien des Konfliktes eingesetzt wurden. Von innerkirch-\nlichen Auseinandersetzungen tiber Hierarchiestreitigkeiten in den provinzialen\nRaten bis hin zu Machtkampfen kaiserlicher Beamter wurden Rituale von unter-\nschiedlichen Akteuren dazu eingesetzt, um ihre jeweiligen Gegner zu bezwin-\ngen.’ In genau diesem Rahmen bewegt sich auch die Funktion von Ritualen in\nBiirgerkriegen. Im vorliegenden Aufsatz soll gezeigt werden, wie Rituale von\nThronpratendenten auf unterschiedlichen Ebenen als strategisches Mittel einge-\nsetzt wurden, um sich im Biirgerkrieg gegen Konkurrenten durchzusetzen. Dabei\nsoll insbesondere herausgearbeitet werden, dass Rituale nicht einfach als symboli-\nsche Handlungen zu verstehen sind, die das Ergebnis von Machtkaémpfen zei-\nchenhaft zum Ausdruck bringen, sondern dass sie selbst zentrale Medien in diesen\nMachtkampfen waren. Exemplarisch gezeigt werden soll dies zunachst anhand der\nKaiserbildversendung, die von Usurpatoren in der Spatantike sehr haufig dazu\ngenutzt wurde, um bei den anderen Herrschern die Anerkennung als Mitkaiser\ndurchzusetzen. In einem zweiten Schritt soll analysiert werden, warum Rituale vor\ndem Hintergrund des rémischen Akzeptanzmodells allgemein so haufig in Btir-\ngerkriegssituationen eingesetzt wurden.\n\niz Greg. Einerseits bedurften die Kaiser Rituale als Ausdruck der Akzeptanz\nder Reichsbevélkerung, andererseits bildeten die Rituale gleichzeitig auch stets\neine potentielle Gefahr, indem sie prinzipiell auch Usurpatoren offenstanden. Un-\nterschiedliche Kaiser versuchten daher, den Einsatz von bestimmten Ritualen zu\nmonopolisieren. Vom Verbot des Constantius, Bilder Julians im Heer aufstellen\nzu lassen, war bereits die Rede. Im Kontext der Friedensverhandilungen zwischen\nPetros Patrikios, dem Gesandten Justinians, und dem Ostgotenkénig Theodahat\nim Jahre 535 hat sich zudem die Vertragsbestimmung tiberliefert, dass weder Bil-\nder von Theodahat allein aufgestellt noch der Ostgotenkénig vor Justinian akkila-\nmiert werden durfte,® was faktisch bedeutete, dass Theodahat den formellen Herr-\nschaftsanspruch Justinians tiber Italien anerkennen sollte.*7 Die Tatsache, dass\nPetros Patrikios so sehr auf diese Punkte insistierte, zeigt die hohe Bedeutung, die\ndie Akteure den entsprechenden Ritualen zumaBen. Wie jedoch der extensive Ein-\nsatz von Ritualen in spatantiken Biirgerkriegen zeigt, scheiterten die Kaiser darin,\nkaiserliche Rituale wie Akklamationen und Bilderaufstellungen zu monopolisie-\nren.** Wie hatten sie es auch verhindern sollen, dass ein Usurpator seine Portrats\nan die Provinzialstadte versandte, einen Adventus inszenierte oder seine Claqueu-\nre Akklamationen rufen lie8? Insgesamt muss daher festgestellt werden, dass Ri-\ntuale aufgrund des rémischen Akzeptanzsystems unerlasslich fiir die rémische\nMonarchie waren, jedoch gerade deshalb auch sehr effektiv von Usurpatoren ein-\ngesetzt werden konnten.\n\n \n\nFAZIT\n\nIn diesem Aufsatz sollte gezeigt werden, dass Rituale auf mehreren Ebenen ideal\ndazu geeignet waren, um als strategisches Mittel in Biirgerkriegssituationen ein-\ngesetzt zu werden. Besonders betont wurde dabei, dass Rituale nicht nur als sym-\nbolische Medien verstanden werden sollten, sondern ganz konkret eine erhebliche\npolitische Bedeutung besaBen. Zum einen boten Rituale durch ihre Strukturhaf-\ntigkeit die Méglichkeit, ihren Einsatz im Vorfeld zu planen, was sie zu einem her-\nvorragenden strategischen Instrument machte. Auf kommunikationstheoretischer Ebene\nstellten Rituale somit einen kommunikativen Code zur Verfiigung, der sowohl\nvom Sender als auch vom Empfanger verstanden werden und somit als Interakti-\nonsmedium eingesetzt werden konnte. Durch die feste Struktur eines Rituals\nwussten alle Akteure, welche Handlungen notwendig waren, damit es ,,richtig“\ndurchgefiihrt wurde. Wenn etwa die Kaiserbilder nicht entsprechend dem Ritu-\nalskript aufgenommen wurden, war das Ritual gescheitert. Somit war auch eine\n»Nicht-Handlung* eine Handlung. Rituale erzwangen somit eine Reaktion und\nverhinderten Neutralitat. Konstantin wusste, dass Galerius auf seine Bildversen-\ndung hin reagieren musste und setzte ihn somit unter Druck, ihn entweder anzuer-\nkennen oder einen Biirgerkrieg auszuldsen. Maxentius und Leontios wiederum\nwussten, dass sie durch die Versendung ihrer Portrats die Provinzstadte zu einer\nklaren Positionierung zwingen wiirden. Gerade die Strukturhaftigkeit von Ritua-\nlen erméglichten somit tiberhaupt erst die Méglichkeit zu ihrem strategischen Ein-\nsatz.\n\nZum anderen beruhte die Effektivitét von Ritualen als Medium in spatantiken\nBiirgerkriegen auf dem Prinzip des rémischen Akzeptanzsystems. Rituale waren\nim Rémischen Reich ein zentrales Medium, um die ftir einen Kaiser ftir seine Le-\ngitimitat notwendige Akzeptanz bei der Bevélkerung zum Ausdruck zu bringen,\nweshalb selbst Rituale wie die Kaiserbildverehrung und der Kaiserkult in der\nSpatantike weitergeftihrt wurden, obwohl sie die gesamte Kaiserzeit tiber von\nchristlicher Seite heftig bekampft worden waren.’ Der Kaiser bedurfte imperialer\nRituale, da einzig Akzeptanz einen Kaiser von einem Usurpator unterschied. Da\nes die Kaiser jedoch nicht vermochten, die Handlungsmacht tiber die Rituale zu\nmonopolisieren, waren diese in ihrer Bedeutung ambivalent. Indem auch Usurpa-\ntoren dieselben Rituale wie der Kaiser einsetzen konnten, war es ihnen méglich,\ndurch sie performativ vom Usurpator zum Kaiser zu werden. Zusammengefasst\nlasst sich somit feststellen: Kaiserliche Rituale waren tatsaéchlich Mittel der Herr-\nschaftsaustibung und Mittel der Konsensbildung. Doch gerade dies machte sie zu\nidealen Medien fiir Usurpationen. Indem auch in der Spatantike noch die Position\ndes Kaisers auf der Akzeptanz durch unterschiedliche Akteure beruhte, konnten\nUsurpatoren durch Rituale, die aufgrund ihrer Strukturhaftigkeit auBerst flexibel\neingesetzt werden konnten, performativ den Beweis vollbringen, die Akzeptanz\nzu besitzen, die nétig war, um ein legitimer Herrscher sein zu kénnen.\n\n \n\n \n\nLITERATUR\n\nALFGLDI, A., 1934.             "result": " \n\nThe Impaled King: A Head and Its Context 431\n\nIf at least the basic drift of the hypothetical reconstruction presented here is\ncorrect, the reworked sestertius is a striking illustration of how former followers\nof Maximinus wanted their pragmatic decision to overthrow the emperor to be\nunderstood and how they tried to legitimate their change of sides. By ostenta-\ntiously distancing themselves from Maximinus, they maintained their significance\nas players in the game of Empire: by being the first to take part in the damnatio\nmemoriae against Maximinus, the milites showed that their defection from their\nformer sovereign and (re-)integration in the political order of the Roman Empire\nwere genuine.\n\nBIBLIOGRAPHY\n\nALRAM, M., 1989. A favorite word in the\nlanguage of Justinian’s compilers and appears fre-\nquently in interpolated texts. The consecratio, both capitis and bonorum,\nis the lot of a person whom the laws declared saczr.\n—See LEGES SACRATAE,\n\nWissowa, RE 4; De Ruggiero, DE 1, 144,\n\nConsecratio. (From consentire.) In private law = con-\nsent. It is either unilateral when a person gives his\nassent (approval) to an act performed by another\n(consensus curatoris, of a father or parents, of a\nmagistrate), or bilateral when two persons agree\nupon a transaction. The consensus must be complete\n(in unum = on the same matter) and free from any\nexternal influence (duress = vis, metus, error). Al-\nthough consensus is the basic element of all agree-\nments between two or more persons, there are some\ncontracts (emptio venditio, locatio conductio, man-\ndatum, societas) which are concluded (obligatio con-\nsensu contracta) when merely a consensus of the\nparties exists and is expressed (nudus consensus),\nas opposed to other contracts for the conclusion of\nwhich further elements are required, such as the\ndelivery of a thing (res), the use of words (verba)\nor a written form (litterae). Consensus may be given\nexpressly in spoken or written words, or tacitly, sim-\nply by-gesture or other behavior leaving no doubt as\nto the consent of the party (facite, tacitus consensus).\n—Inst. 3.22.—-See CONTRACTUS, NUTUS.\n\nLeonhard, RE 4; Perozzi, St Schupfer, 1 (Turin, 1898) ;\nHagerstrém, ZSS 63 (1943) 268,\n\nConsensus. A consensual contract (see\nCONSENSUS} could be rescinded by a contrary agree-\nment of the parties if neither of them had yet fulfilled\nhis obligation (re integra, re nondum soluta). Follow-\ning a Republican institution, the council of the magis-\ntrates (CONSILIUM MaGIsTRATUUM), the emperors\nbeginning with Augustus used to consult a body of\nadvisors convoked in cases of particular importance.\nHadrian organized it as a permanent council com-\nposed of members (jurists, high imperial function-\naries of equestrian rank, and senators) appointed for\nlife (consiliarit, from the time of Diocletian a consiliis\nsacris). In the later Empire the council, called con-\nsistorium (sacrum), functioned rather as a privy\ncouncil of the emperor in legislative, judicial and\nadministrative matters. Many famous jurists of the\nclassical period were members of the consilium. They\nexercised a great influence on the development of the\nlaw as crystallized in imperial enactments. The par-\nticipation of the praetorian prefects gave the consilium\nprincipis also a political character.\n\nOrestano, NDI 3; Balsdon, OCD; Seeck, RE 4, 926; De\nRuggiero, DE 2, 614; Cuq, Mémoires de l Académie des\nInser. et Belles-Lettres, 1 S. 9 (1884); Cicogna, If con-\nsilium principis, consistorium, 1902; idem, I consigli det\nmagistrati romani e il cons. princ., 1910; Orestano, Il\npotere normativo degli imperatori, 1937, 51.\n\nConsilium propinquorum (necessariorum). Such principles were established in the early\nsecond century after Christ. We are told by Gaius\n(Cloc. cit.) that there never had been any doubt about\nit, and yet in the early Principate the emperor used\nto present his legislative proposals personally-in an\noratio before the senate for its approval by which they\nacquired full legal force. This approval afterwards\nbecame a simple formality, so that the oratio itself\nwas considered a law. A legislative character was\nattributed in the first place to the edicta and to those\nenactments indicated as constitutiones generales (de-\ncreta, rescripta) in which the emperor expressly de-\nclared that his decision issued in a specific case should\nhenceforth be applied in analogous cases. Rescripts\nand decrees issued without such a clause also acquired\nthe force of legal norms in the last analysis, since\non the one hand the judges normally followed the\nprinciples settled therein (although legally they were\nnot bound to do so) and on the other hand by appeal\n\nADOLF BERGER\n\n[TRANS, AMER. A formless promise to pay an already\nexisting debt, either of one’s own (constitutum debiti\nproprii) or of another (constitutum debiti alient) on\na fixed date and at a fixed place. The sum so prom-\nised is called pecunia constituta. This is not a nova-\ntion, the creditor being able to sue the debtor according\nto the previous terms. In transactions governed\nby bona fides (negotia bonae fidei) and protected by\nactions (iudicia) bonae fidei the judge’s duty was to\ntake into consideration fraudulent conduct of the\nparties and to reject claims or defenses based on\ndolus. A theft committed by an illicit use of\na thing, which one obtained from the owner for a\nspecific purpose, against the owner’s will and beyond\nthe limits imposed by the latter. Such a theft oc-\ncurred, for example, when a depositary, a receiver\nof a commodatum, a creditor holding a pledge used\nthe thing for other purposes than agreed upon. The\nclassical origin of the term is rather doubtful.\n\nC. Ferrini, Opere 5 (1930, written 1886) 107; M. Pampa-\ntoni, Scritti giuridici 1 (1947) 717 (written 1894).\n\nFustigatio, fustis. See CASTIGATIO, CRUX.\n\nFustuarium supplicium. The execution of a slave\nor a deserter condemned to death by beating him with\nclubs.—Sée CASTIGATIO, DESERERE.\n\nFutura. See pRAETERITA,\n\nG\n\nGaius. One of the most renowned Roman jurists of\nthe middle of the second century after Christ (born\nunder Hadrian). His origin, full name and personal\n\nENCYCLOPEDIC DICTIONARY OF ROMAN LAW\n\n481\n\nwhereabouts are unknown. For his standard work,\nthe Institutes, see INSTITUTIONES GAI, Moreover, he\nwrote a series of works, among them a commentary\non the Twelve Tables and commentaries on the Edict\nof the praetor urbanus and the provincial edict. No\nother jurist commented on the provincial edict, see\nEDICTUM PROVINCIALE, An elementary work, RES\nCOTTIDIANAE (called also Aurea) is ascribed to him,\nbut several scholars believe it to be a postclassical\ncompilation of excerpts from Gaius’ works. Mono-\ngraphs on legal institutions (on fideicommissa, on\nmanumissions) appear under his name. In spite of\nthis rich literary activity he is never cited by the\nclassical jurists. Some sporadic mentions of a Gaius\nrefer to the jurist Gaius Cassius Longinus (see\ncassius). Later (A.D, 426) Gaius appears among\nthe jurists whose opinions acquired official authority\nin the so-called Law of Citations (see 1URISPRUDEN-\nTIA). Justinian considerably contributed to his fame\nby utilizing his Institutes as a basic source for the\nimperial Institutiones and speaking of him with great\nesteem (“Gaius noster”)—See INSTITUTIONES GAI,\nINSTITUTIONES IUSTINIANI,\nKubler, RE 7; Orestano, NDI 6; Berger, OCD; F. The humane tendency as an ethical com-\nmandment, benevolent consideration for others. The\nterm as well as the adjective humanus (humanior)\nappears both in juristic texts and imperial constitu-\ntions. The idea of humanity undoubtedly exercised\na considerable influence on the development of the\nRoman law through interpretation and decisions of\nthe jurists. In the Christian Empire its influence\ninfiltrated various provinces of the law (family, mar-\nriage, succession, slavery, penal legislation). It is\nundeniable that many a decision introduced by phrases\nlike sed humanius est or similar, is not of classical\norigin; on the other hand, however, it is not correct\nto ascribe every passage where the expression hu-\nmanitas occurs and every decision based on humani-\ntarian principles to postclassical (Christian) times or\nto Justinian. Humanitas and humanus cannot be com-\npletely eliminated from the juristic language and\nthinking. What appeared good (humane) to Cicero,\ncould not appear contemptible to the jurists. Legates of senatorial rank as-\n\nsigned regularly or only in war time to the legati\nAugusti pro praetore who were commanders of le-\ngions in the provinces, in order to assist them in\nmilitary, administrative and judicial activity.\n\nLiebenam, RE 6, 1641; v. Premerstein, RE 12, 1142, 1147,\n\nENCYCLOPEDIC DICTIONARY OF ROMAN LAW\n\n539\n\nLegati municipiorum (coloniarum). Delegations sent\nto Rome by provincial municipalities or colonies in\norder to present complaints against (or praise for)\nthe provincial governor or against a magistrate of the\ncolony. Such missions came te Rome also to express\nsome particular wishes or to declare their loyalty to\nRome or the emperor, on the occasion of a happy\nevent. Generally they were composed of three\npersons.\n\nCagnat, DS 3, 1036.\n\nLegati proconsulis. The provincial governor of a\nsenatorial province, who had the rank of a proconsul,\nhad a deputy, legatus proconsulis. The latter had\njurisdiction only as far as it was delegated to him\nby the governor (iurisdictio mandata). His official\ntitle was legatus pro praetore and his imperium was\nof a degree lower (pro praetore) than that of the\ngovernor (pro consule). He replaced the governor\nin the case of absence or death. These legates are to\nbe distinguished from the legati Augusti pro praetore\nin imperial provinces, All legati pro praetore had\nthe right to be preceded by five lictors with fasces,\nhence they were named quinquefascales—D. 1.16;\nC. 1.35.—See PROVINCIA, TURISDICTIO MANDATA and\nthe following item.\n\nV. Premerstein, RE 12, 1143; Lauria, dnMac 3 (1928) 92.\n\nLegati pro praetore. See the foregoing item. Legati\nAugusti (Caesaris) pro praetore = governors of im-\nperial provinces appointed by the emperor for an\nindefinite period. They were representatives of the\nemperor who himself had the proconsular imperium\nand therefore their imperium was only pro practore.\n—Legati Augusti pro praetore could be sent by the\nemperor to senatorial provinces but only for a special\ntask,\n\nV. Premerstein, RE 12, 1144; Bersanetti, DE 4, 527; So-\njazzi, AG 100 (1928) 3.\n\nLegatio. The office of an ambassador, a group of dele-\ngates entrusted with a mission. The head of the\ngroup = princeps legationis—D. 50.7; C. 10.65—\nSee LEGATI, IUS LEGATIONIS, CONCILIA PROVINCIARUM.\n\nLegatio gratuita. See LEGATIVUM.\n\nLegatio libera. An ambassadorship granted by the\nsenate to a senator to facilitate his travel abroad\nin personal matters, He did not assume any official\nduties.\n\nA. v. Premerstein, RE 14, 1185; Jacopi, DE 4, 508.\n\nLegativum. The expenses of an ambassador, primarily\nfor traveling (viaticum). They were reimbursed\nunless the ambassador assumed the mission at his\nown expenses (legatio gratuita).\n\nLegatum. A legacy. It is “a deduction from the\ninheritance” (D. 30.116 pr.) which according to the\ntestator’s wish is given some person other than the\nheir. The legatee (legatarius) is legatarius partiarius\nwhen a fraction of the inheritance is left to him (see\nPARTITIO LEGATA). The term\ncovered various kinds of sorcery, such as the use of\nmagic formulae, nocturnal sacrifices made in order\nto produce supernatural results, the use of magic\nliquids, and the like. A private individual or an official who\narranged public games, especially gladiatorial combats\n(ludi gladiatorii) or fights with wild animals.\n\nSchneider, RE 16.\n\nMunicipalis. (Noun.) A member of the municipal\ncouncil, Municipalis (adj.) connected with, or per-\ntaining to municipia—D. 50.1.—See DECURIONES,\nMUNERA MUNICIPALIA, LEX MUNICIPALIS TARENTINA,\nLEX IULIA MUNICIPALIS, MAGISTRATUS MUNICIPALES,\nand the following items.\n\nMunicipes. Citizens of a municipality (municipium).\nOne became a municeps by birth (see ortco), adop-\ntion by, or manumission by a municeps. The ety-\nmology of the term (munera capere, muneris parti-\ncipes) indicates the principal duties of a municeps\ntowards his municipality: rendering public services\nand assuming charges for the welfare of the com-\nmunity, The municipes have twofold citizenship,\nsince they are Roman citizens and citizens of their\nmunicipium. In their first capacity they participated\nin the political life of the state when present in Rome,\nas citizens of a municipium they took part in the\nlocal administration. By a decree of the municipal\ncouncil (ordo decurionum) municipal citizenship\ncould be granted to individuals who were not entitled\nto it (adlectio inter cives) —D. 50.1; C. 10.39.—See\nACTOR MUNICIPUM, CURIAE MUNICIPIORUM, INCOLA,\nORIGO, MUNICIPIUM.\n\nA. Any town in Italy except Rome (=\nurbs), The term superseded gradually analogous\nexpressions (oppidum, colonia, praefectura) and was\nlater applied also to cities in the provinces. Syn.\ncivitas, and, to a certain extent, res publica, Origi-\nnally there were municipia cum suffragio (with the\nright to vote in popular assemblies) and cum iure\nhonorum. (the right of their citizens to be elected as\nmagistrates in Rome), and municipia sine suffragio\n(deprived of such rights). The municipia had, how-\never, the privilege of local autonomous government\nand jurisdiction. An attempt of a general regulation\nof the municipal organization was made in the so-\ncalled Lex ruLIA MuNIcIPALIS. Other municipal\nstatutes, preserved in inscriptions, are LEX MUNICI-\nPALIS TARENTINA, LEX RUBRIA DE GALLIA CISALPINA,\nLEX COLONIAE GENETIVAE IULIAE, LEX MALACITANA,\nLEX SALPENSANA. A uniform organization of the\nmunicipal administration was not fully established,\nand differences in the titles of the municipal magis-\ntrates, and their functions, as well as the functions\nof the municipal councils, were never completely\neliminated. Under the Republic a municipium could\nnot be instituted as an heir, but this situation im-\nproved in the course of time. First fideicommissa in\nfavor of a municipium were admitted, then a fidei-\ncommissum hereditatis (see SENATUSCONSULTUM\n\nADOLF BERGER\n\n{TRANS, AMER, PHIL, SOC,\n\nAPRONIANUM), and finally under Hadrian the full\ncapacity of municipia to be instituted as an heir or\nlegatee was recognized —D. 50.1—See pecuRIONES,\nORDO DECURIONUM, DUOVIRI IURI DICUNDO, DUOVIRI\nAEDILES, CURIAE MUNICIPIORUM, PATRONUS MUNI-\nCIPII, MAGISTRATUS MUNICIPALES, TABULAE COM-\nMUNES.\nKornemann, RE 16; Toutain, DS 3; Sacchi, NDI 8; W.\nLiebenam, Stadteverwaltung in der Kaiserzeit* (1900) ; L.\nMitteis, Rém.             "result": "620\n\nto a grandfather.—See PATER FAMILIAS, PARENS.\n\nPater farnilias. The head of a family, without regard\nas to whether or not a person so designated has chil-\ndren, whether he is married or is below the age of\npuberty. A pater familias must be a Roman citizen\nand not under paternal power of another. By the\ndeath of a pater familias all sons (and grandsons\nwhose father was dead or had been emancipated)\nwho were directly under his paternal power, became\npaires familias. The pater familias was the first in\nthe family (princeps familiae) and was the master of\nthe “house” (in domo dominium habet), His power\nlasted as long as he lived, without regard to the age\nof the persons under his paternal power (patria\npotestas) or their official position. His power was\nboundless and limited only by custom and social\ntradition, He alone has the right to dispose of the\nfamily property. —C. 4.13; 43——~See PATRIA POTESTAS,\nFILIUS FAMILIAS, BONUS PATER FAMILIAS, DILIGENS\nPATER FAMILIAS, EMANCIPATIO, INTERDICTUM DE\nLIBERIS EXHIBENDIS.\n\nSachers, RE 18, 4, 2121 (Bibl.); Anon. NDI 9; Longo,\nBIDR 40 (1932) 201; C. Grant, From imperium to auctoritas,\n1946, p. 444 (Bibi).\n\nPater solitarius. A widower and father of legitimate\nchildren who after the death of his wife remained\nunmarried. The Lex Iulia et Papia Poppaea con-\ntained a provision concerning the pater solitarius as\na COELEBS, but its content is unknown—See LEX\nIULIA DE MARITANDIS ORDINIBUS.\n\nSolazzi, ANap 61 (1942) 184.\n\nPati. To suffer, to bear (a loss, an injury, damages) ;\nwith regard to civil judicial matters = to be involved\nin a controversy or a trial (pati controversiam,\nactionem, interdictum, exceptionem); in criminal\nmatters to incur a punishment (poenant).\n\nPatientia servitutis. Occurred when the owner of\nland tolerated the exercising by another (a neighbor)\n\nADOLF BERGER\n\n[rRans. AMER, PHEL, SOC,\n\nof certain rights (usus servitutis) on his property,\nsuch as ITER, acTus, and the like. This toleration\nwas not understood as a simple passive attitude but\nas a tacit expression of the will of the owner and a\nrecognition as if the other were entitled to exercise\nan easement on account of a previous agreement (the\nconstitution of a servitude). In classical law the\nbeneficiary could use the AcTIO PUBLICIANA, in Jus-\ntinian’s law the patientia is identified with a volun-\ntary concession of a servitude (traditio servitutis).\nSee Perozzi, Seritti 2 (1948, ex 1897); Rabel, Mél Girard\n2 (1912) 394; Guarneri-Citati, Indice? (1927) 64; B.-\nBiondi, Servitd prediali, 1948, 229; S. Solazzi, Requisiti\ne modi di costitusione di servith pred., 1947, 149.\n\nPatientiam praestare. To tolerate another’s (a neigh-\nbor’s) entering into one’s property and performing\nthere certain acts (such as the demolition of a con-\nstruction which was harmful to a neighbor’s property\nand which the owner was obligated to carry out but\nfailed). This occurred usually when a person other\nthan the owner of a landed property (his lessee, slave,\nor predecessor in title) built a construction which\ncaused or threatened to cause damage to a neighbor’s\nproperty. Such construction could be averted by a\nprotesting action on the part of the neighbor (see\nOPERIS NOVI NUNTIATIO, ACTIO AQUAE PLUVIAE AR-\nCENDAE). If the harmful construction was not de-\nstroyed by the owner or his lessee, the neighbor\nmight do it at his own expense (which, of course,\nhad to be reimbursed by the owner) and the owner\nhad to tolerate such action on his land—See the\nforegoing item.\n\nPatres. The oldest term denoting the members of the\nking’s senate which presumably was composed of the\n“fathers,” ie. the heads of the gentes (see GENS)\nand prominent families. Livy says that the earliest\nsenators were called patres for dignity’s sake (propter\nhonorem). The relatives of the patres and their\ndescendants formed the class of patricii (patricians).\nHence patres was used as syn. with patricii, as, e.g.,\nin the norm of the Twelve Tables which forbade mar-\nriage between plebeians and patricians (paires) —See\nAUCTORITAS PATRUM,\n\nKiibler, RE 18, 4, 2222,\n\nPatres conscripti. Originally the plebeian members of\nthe senate when, about the middle of the fourth cen-\ntury B.c., the plebeians were admitted to the senate,\ntheir selection being determined by the censors..\nLater, the term patres conscripti was applied to sena-\ntors without distinction as to whether they were\npatricians or plebeians.\n\nBrassloff, RE 4; De Ruggiero, DE 2, 604; O’Brien-Moore,\nRE Suppl. 6, 674; Meurs, Mn 55 (1927) 377.\n\nPatria. The native country, the fatherland. “Rome is\nour common native country” (D. 50.1.33: Roma\ncommunis nostra patria est). For patria in the mean-\ning of the entire Roman state, see PATER PATRIAE.\n\nE. De Ruggiero, Lo patria nel dir. pubblico, 1921; L. A foreigner, a stranger, a citizen of a\nstate other than Rome. A great majority of the\npopulation of Rome were peregrines, subjects of\nRome after the conquest of their country by Rome.\nWith the increase of the Roman state the number\nof peregrines grew constantly without being com-\npensated by the number of new citizens to whom\nRoman citizenship was granted. Within Roman ter-\nritory the peregrines enjoyed the rights of free per-\nsons unless a treaty between Rome and their native\ncountry granted them specific rights. Generally, the\nlegislation under the Republic, both statutes and\nsenaiusconsulta, applied to peregrines only when a\nparticular provision extended their validity to them.\nPeregrines had no political rights, they could not par-\nticipate in the popular assemblies, and were excluded\nfrom military service. A peregrinus might conclude\na valid marriage (iustae nuptiae) only when he had\nthe rus conuBir (see conuBIUM), either granted to\nhim personally or acquired through his citizenship\nin a civitas which obtained this right from Rome.\nA peregrine could not make a testament in the forms\nreserved for Roman citizens nor act as a witness\nthereto. He could not be instituted an heir of a\nRoman citizen nor receive a legacy (legatum) except\nin a testament of a soldier. He was able to conclude\na commercial transaction with a Roman citizen if\nhe had the 1us comMerctt, which was granted in the\nsame ways as ius conubti, Though excluded from the\nproceedings by LEGIS ACTIO, a peregrine had the\nbenefit of protection in Roman courts, in particular\nbefore that praetor who had jurisdiction inter pere-\ngrinos (see PRAETORES) from the middle of the third\ncentury B.c. Certain actions were gradually made\navailable to peregrines and against them by the means\nof a fiction “as if he were a Roman citizen”; see\nACTIONES FICTICIAE. Foreigners from the same state\nconcluded transactions in accordance with the laws\nof that state and litigations among them were settled\naccording to their own laws. A peregrine who ob-\ntained Roman citizenship (see CIVITAS ROMANA)\nceased to be a peregrine whether he obtained it\nas a personal grant or within a large group. The\nsharp distinction between cives and peregrini lost\nits emphasis in the legal field in the course of time\nas a result of the development of commercial rela-\ntions between Romans and peregrines. On the other\nhand the extension of Roman citizenship which at the\nend of the Republic was conferred on the entire\npopulation of Italy, furthered the disappearance of\nthe once very sensible differences. The CoNSTITUTIO\nANTONINIANA did the rest. In Justinian’s law the\nonly peregrines were the barbarians (see BARBARI).\n-~For the exceptional status of the Latins, see La-\nTIUM, IUS LATII, LATINI.             "result": "650\n\nbut elective; election by the senate as representatives\nof the people was the rule. There was, however, at\ntimes a hereditary succession, in fact, when an em-\nperor indicated his successor (a natural or adoptive\nson, or a near relative) by designating the latter as\nhis heir thereby implying the wish that his heir might\nbe also his successor as the princeps. A similar\ndesignation of a successor might be expressed by the\nappointment of a co-regent. The juridical structure\nof the Principate has remained controversial in spite\nof a tremendous literature in recent times on the occa-\nsion of Augustus’ bimillenary. The Principate can\nhardly be classified as a uniform constitutional system.\nIt started from the tendency of Augustus to keep in\nforce certain Republican institutions, but in the course\nof time some authoritarian features were added at\nthe expense of earlier democratic elements, so that\nthe constitutional aspect at the beginning of the Prin-\ncipate was gradually disappearing in later times, par-\nticularly under Hadrian and in the late first half of\nthe third century. With the reign of Diocletian a\nnew epoch started in the Roman constitutional devel-\nopment with an autocratic monarch at the head of the\nempire (no more princeps, but imperator). This\nperiod is termed (perhaps not very appropriately)\nDominate, the emperor being now (from the time\nof Aurelian, a.p. 270-275) the master, dominus, over\nthe territory and the population of the state. Descendants were\nnot admitted to testimony in matters concerning their\nascendants and vice versa; similarly freedmen and\ntheir descendants with regard to their manumitters.\nThere were no strict rules for the evaluation of the\ntestimony of witnesses and of other means of evi-\ndence. The judges were advised to “explore exactly\nwhether a witness was worthy of confidence” (D.\n22.5.3 pr.) through exaniination of his social situa-\ntion, his financial condition, his moral reliability\n(eg., whether he would do anything for profit) and\nthe like. A witness present\nat the making of a testament. The capacity of a\nperson to be a witness to a specific testament is also\ntermed TESTAMENTI FACTIO. The witness had to be\ninvited (see TESTIS ROGATUS)—not forced—to serve\nand to be present near the testator during the entire\nact. He should know that it was a will which he\nwitnessed, but the contents could remain unknown\nto him. At the opening of the testament (see APER-\nTURA TESTAMENTI) he had to recognize the authen-\nticity of his seal. Specific restrictions were imposed\nwith regard to witnesses belonging to the immediate\nfamily of the testator. See TESTAMENTUM DOMESTI-\ncum. Women and slaves were excluded. The rules\nconcerning the admission of a person (or persons\nsubject to his paternal power) to witness a testament\nin which he was instituted as an heir were finally\nsettled by Justinian who excluded them all. Legatees,\nhowever, were admitted ——-See TESTAMENTUM, QUAES-\nTIO DOMITIANA, SCRIPTOR TESTAMENTI,\n\nKaser, RE SA, 1041; B. Biondi, Successione testamentaria\n(1943) 59.\n\nTestis idoneus. A treasure-trove, a valuable movable (pri-\nmarily money) which had been hidden for so long a\ntime so that its actual owner was unknown and his\nidentity could no longer be established. The finder\nof a thesaurus (inventor thesauri) could keep it for\nhimself if he found it on his own land or in a sacred\nplace (locus sacer or religiosus). Uf he found it in\nanother’s land by accident, only one-half belonged to\nhim and the other half to the landowner. If the\nthesaurus was found in ground which was a locus\npublicus, the finder shared the thesaurus with the fisc.\nA finder who did not report his find to the fisc when\nthe latter was entitled to a half, lost his share and\nhad to pay the entire amount of the thesaurus to the\nfisc. Finding a thesaurus in another’s land through\ndeliberate search gave the finder no right at all—\nCc. 10.15.\nKiibler, RE 6A; Dorigny, DS 5; Ravetta, L’acquisto di\ntesoro, 1910; Bonfante, Mél Girard 1 (1912) 123 (= Scritit\n2 [1926] 904}; Schulz, ZSS 35 (1914) 94; Appleton, St\nBonfante 3 (1930) 1; G. A beam used for the construction\nof a house; in a broader sense, any material used for\nthat purpose. According to the rule, superficies cedit\nsolo (see SUPERFICIES) the owner of the building\nbecame owner of the material used even if it originally\nbelonged to another. The latter could not sue the\nowner for the recovery of the material as long as the\nhouse stood firm; if it collapsed or if the material\nwas separated in some other way, he might then claim\nhis property. He had an action, however, the actio\nde tigno iuncto, against the owner for double the\nvalue of the material if the latter was used in bad\nfaith (e.g., if it was stolen). A claim for separation\nof the material was not permissible. Justinian intro-\nduced the 1us TOLLEND! in favor of the owner of the\nmaterial—D. 47.3.—-See SERVITUS TIGNI IMMITTENDI.\n\nChapot, DS 5; Ehrhardt, RE 6A; E. In his reign occurred the greatest symbolic event\nexperienced by the capital during this period —— the Avar siege of 626,\nwith its proof of the city’s protection by the Virgin — and when\nHeraclius made his triumphal return from Persia in 628 he was greeted\nby people and patriarch not with a Roman triumph but with hymns of\npraise to God.*” In 629 he set the seal on this change of direction by\ngiving up the traditional imperial titulature which went back to the\ndays of Augustus and officially adopting instead the Greek term\nbasileus (emperor) —- but not basileus alone: henceforth the em-\nperor was to be known as the “believing” emperor (pistos en Christo\nbasileus).*® Texts of the same period refer often to the “Christ-loving”\nemperor;*? and while earlier emperors also had been the pious servants\nof God, as Justinian was shown at Ravenna, it was only now that\nthey were willing to give up six hundred years of imperial tradition.\nCertainly the climate was changing with Justin Il, who inserted the\ntitle of Christ as King of Kings into the liturgy®! and made explicit in\nhis own building programme the twin conceptions of the emperor as\nthe image of Christ and Christ as the rex regnantium. In\nagrarian and military history the most extreme dislocation of\nByzantine society occurred in the seventh rather than the sixth\ncentury, and recent administrative studies tend to put emphasis on\ncontinuity up to the seventh century as well as rupture.!45 Late sixth-\ncentury authors complain about neglect, but do not suggest that they\nfelt the system as a whole was breaking down; indeed they expect their\nemperors to continue the militaristic pattern set by Justinian,'4° and\nboth emperors and writers still hold to the fundamentally optimistic\nview that earthly success would be the guaranteed reward of right\nideology in a God-protected empire.!4” Yet recent experience seemed\nto suggest that something was missing.             "result": "16 CHAPTER ONE\n\nto be used until today in popular and political discourses developed in\nthe wider region”\n\nThe problem of Croat origins is even more open for different manip-\nulations, taking into account the Slavic characteristics of medieval\nCroats, such as personal names or language, and the suspiciously non-\nSlavic ethnonym Hrvat, pl. Hrvati (Croat, Croats), which was at one\ntime or another recognised in scholarship as Sarmatian, Persian,\nTurkic, Gothic, etc. This chapter will explore the ways in which Croat\norigins have been seen throughout history, as well as the current popu-\nlar views of Croat origins. Certainly, this is a very broad topic, and the\npurpose will be to underline the most important and prevailing\ndiscourses.®\n\nThe discourses on Croat origins\n\nThe discourses on Croat origins, as much as the discourses on the ori-\ngins of other South Slavs, started to appear in chapters 29-31 of the\nDe Administrando Imperio, written in the mid-i0th century by the\nByzantine emperor Constantine VII Porphyrogenitus, and resurfaced\nin the 12th or 13th centuries, when the Presbyter Diocleas and Thomas\nthe Archdeacon of Spalatum tried to explain the appearance of Slavic\nidentities in the region. This problem, thanks to insufficient sources,\ntickled the imagination of Croatian and other intellectuals throughout\nthe Renaissance and the Enlightenment, up to the present day. There\nare several discourses, ‘schools of thought, or ‘models, which some-\ntimes reflect the times in which they developed and the political ideals\nof those scholars who contributed to these discourses, rather than pro-\nviding an accurate scholarly assessment of the past. We can divide\nthese discourses on origins as ‘migrationist, observing Croats as arriv-\nals in post-Roman Illyricum, whether as Slavs, Goths, Iranians, or\nTurks, and the ‘autochthonist, which viewed them as indigenous.’\n\nThe ‘autochthon Slav’ discourse derived from Renaissance times,\nwhich linked early modern Slav identities with the ancient construction\nof Illyricum, as well as the ancient perception of the indigenous\n\n \n\n \n\nKaiser 1995; Novakovi¢ 2007; Madgearu 2008; 195-200.\n® See for more in depth analysis, Katicic 1999a; 1999b; Budak 2009b, and in a wider\ncomparative context of non-Slav discourses of origines amongs South Slavs see recently\nBrunnbauer 2006.\n’ The migrationist discourses can also be divided into ‘Slav’ and ‘anti-Slav, as in\nKaticié 1999a: 155 ff\n\n \n\n \n\n \n\n \n\f"

            "result": "Journal of Hellenic Studies cxvii (1997) pp 60-86\n\nTHE NIKA RIOT: A REAPPRAISAL\n\nTHE uprising which took place in Constantinople in January 532 has long attracted the\nattention of scholars, the first significant contribution being J.B. Bury’s magisterial article of\n1897.' My present aim is to re-examine the Nika riot, and to set it in its wider context: it will\nbe argued that the significant place assigned to it in accounts of the reign of Justinian distorts\nthe reality of late fifth-sixth century Constantinople. The riot was by no means an isolated\noutbreak of popular discontent, but just one in a whole series of bloody confrontations in the\ncapital.” It has engaged the interest of historians more than other disturbances for the same\nreason that Justinian’s reign attracts such frequent biographies, while Anastasius’ remains\nneglected: the wealth of sources available for the riot of 532 is much greater than for any other\nsuch event.\n\nConstantinople, like the other major cities of the eastern empire in the early sixth century,\nwas a violent place.? This stemmed in part from the existence of bands of partisans whose\nactivities reached their peak in this period; these will be discussed more fully later. More\ngeneral causes can be traced, however. A general increase in population has been observed,\nwhich was eventually brought to a sudden halt by the plague that swept the empire in 541-2 and\nat regular intervals thereafter.‘ The imperial capital was the destination of many provincials—to\nsuch an extent that Justinian was forced to create a new post in 539, that of quaesitor, in order\nto check the large numbers arriving in Constantinople. In 532 it is known that there had recently\nbeen an influx of provincials into the capital, who may have come in part to protest at measures\n\n} The Nika riot’, JHS xvii (1897) 92-119, cf. 1.B. Bury, History of the later Roman empire from the death of\nTheodosius I to the death of Justinian ii (New York-London 1958) 39-48. There is a detailed treatment of the\nuprising by A.A. Chekalova, Konstatinopol’ v VI veke. Vosstanie Nika (Moscow 1986, henceforth Konstantinopol’),\ncf. eadem, ‘Narod i senatorskaja oppozitsija v vosstanii Nika’, Vizantiskij Vremennik xxxii (1971) 24-39; note also\nthe review of the book by F. Tinnefeld in JOBG xxxviii (1988) 442-4. Mention should be made of the extensive\ndiscussion of the riot in C. Gizewski, Zur Normativitdt und Struktur der Verfassungsverhdiltnisse in der spiiteren\nrémischen Kaiserzeit, Miinchener Beitrage zur Papyrus-forschung und antiken Rechtsgeschichte H.81 (Munich 1988),\nwho considers the riot from a sociological perspective.\n\nBriefer accounts may be found in E. Stein, Histoire du bas-empire ii (Paris 1949) 449-56, J. Martindale, Public\ndisorders in the late Roman empire, unpublished B.Litt. thesis (Oxford 1960) 32-5, A. Cameron, Circus factions:\nBlues and Greens at Rome and Byzantium (Oxford 1976) 278-80, J. Moorhead, Justinian (London 1994) 44-9 and,\nmost recently, J.A.S. Evans, The age of Justinian: the circumstances of imperial power (London 1996) 119-25.\n\niam grateful to Cyril Mango, James Howard-Johnston, Sam Lieu, John Matthews, Michael Whitby and Thanos\nFotiou for comments on this paper; it has also benefited significantly from the comments of the anonymous readers.\n\n? L. Dindorf (Bonn 1831) 395-8 (tr. E. Jeffreys, M. Jeffreys and R. Scott, John Malalas. The\nchronicle [Melbourne 1986] 222-3), cf. Cameron, Circus factions, 198-201 on factions throughout the east. For a\ncatalogue of riots elsewhere, cf. Gizewski (n.1) 206.\n\n3 Cf. e.g. Cameron, Circus factions, 294, on the ‘relatively high level of popular disorder’ tolerated by Roman\nemperors, noted too by P. Veyne, tr. B. Patlagean, Pauvreté économique et pauvreté sociale\na Byzance, 4e-7e siécles (Paris 1977) 213 and Averil Cameron, The Mediterranean world in late antiquity (London\n1993) 171-4. From 500 it may have become yet more violent as a result of the closure of the theatres and the\nconsequent unification of theatre and circus rowdies, cf. Cameron, Circus factions, 225-7 and id., Porphyrius the\ncharioteer (Oxford 1973) 232, 239; but as Patlagean, op. cit., 211, notes, Anastasius’ measures were not wholly\nsuccessful.             "result": "The Government of the late Late Roman City 121\n\nwhich is very different from the sophisticated constitutionalism of the classical\ncity.\n\nFrom government by curiales to government by notables.\n\nIt is clear that the loss of control by the councils was a gradual process. A plausible\nexplanation of the development was given by Libanius towards the end of the\nfourth century. The maintenance of curial strength depended essentially on the\ncuriales themselves. If they did not keep their colleagues to their duties nobody\ncould. But the most powerful councillors did not mind their colleagues’ departure\nfor it meant that they could concentrate power in their own hands.! The\nconsideration that they would also have to bear a larger share of the financial\nburdens ceased to carry much weight as the civic services which councillors had\npaid to provide, that is public buildings, banquets, spectacles, and competitions\ncame to be valued less, or were financed in different ways. On the other hand there\nwas little reason why an ordinary decurion should want to remain in his council. If\nhe was well connected he was likely to win more wealth and esteem in the imperial\nservice or the church. In any case he was likely to enjoy a more carefree life outside\nthe council. Councillors were at risk of being beaten or bankrupted, and this risk\nwas no longer compensated by the prospect of high esteem in the city. So they left.\n\nThe government did its utmost right up to the reign of Justinian to stop this\ntrend through legislation,” but to little effect. In the East the notables were already in\ncontrol by the reign of Anastasius. The government recognised the situation, and\nnew legislation took account of this fact. This may well have been an important\nfactor in the Justinianic revival.3 In the West the process may have taken a little\nlonger but the outcome was the same: the government had to find ways of raising\nthe resources it needed in peace or war through agencies other than decurions,‘ and\nperhaps in the seventh century gave up collecting the basic land-tax altogether.’ It is\nnevertheless possible to isolate the point of time when the process was complete. In\nan oration of 514-15 the orator Priscian praised the emperor Anastasius for\nlightening the tax-burden of the peasantry in consequence of all the curiae having\nabandoned their perverse habits. Malalas writing in the reign of Justinian is more\ndefinite. Marinus, praetorian prefect 512-15, ‘dismissed all members of the city\ncouncils and in their place created the vindices, as they are known in each city of the\nRoman state.’? But these comparatively rare ceremonics were not the\nonly means by which Roman emperors could magnify and\nproject their victory. Vestment, titulature, monuments, imperial\ncoinage and Romar religion all reflected and refracted different\naspects of the imperial ideology of victory. The identification of\nemperor and victor was externalized and reinforced by customs of\nimperial costume. Auyustus himself wore trumphal dress at\nfestivals and spectacles. His successors continued to extend its use\nuntil, inthe third century, an opposite developmentsetin, by which\nthe toga triumphalis became increasingly identified with consular\nfestivities, 4%\n\nJust as the emperor conveyed an image of his function and\nqualifications by his choice of public garb, so the names or ctles by\nwhich he was addressed could mirror varying aspects of imperial\nideology: In the first three centuries we find victory titles of two\nmain types: additional personal names or cognomens derived\nfrom the mames of vanquished peoples (cognomina devictarum\ngentivm) and the epithet ‘unconquered’ (invtetus; avicytac).\n\nCognomens derived from the names of conquered peoples go\nback to the Republic and were systemanzed under the carly\nempire.*?             "result": "Victory celebrations and the throne\n\nent sovereign. He was but a defeated usurper, a rebel against the\nRoman order.7°?\n\nProcopius’ description of the victory celebration of 534 reveals a\ncomposite ceremony whose constituent elements are easily identi-\nfable within late Roman society's repertory of public ritual. The\nexternal forms of the processions were typically late antique. Yet\nProcopius presents the whole extravaganza as a unique restoration\nof ancient Roman tradition, a great leap backward of some six\ncenturies.7°8 Although some have been quick to perceive Kaiser-\nkritik in Procopius’ assertion,*?” is it not more likely that he is\nechoing the original, official interpretation of this staged event?\nAfter all, Justinian is well known for his insistence that his reign\nwas essentially a return to the good old days of ancient lore. What\nmore effective way to innovate in victory ritual than by staging\nwhat was billed as a return to the pristine traditions of ancient\nRome? This interpretation is only strengthened by che consider-\nation that the chief officer for imperial ecrermonial at the time of\nBelisarius’ parade was none other than Tribonian, a lawyer decp-\nly imbued with the splendors of Roman antiquity.24° At any\nrate, after the Imovation of the célebration of §74, Helisarins was\nallowed tw celebrate his victory in more customary fashion, by\nassuming the consulate. In so domg, he enjoyed the traditional\nreward bestowed on victorious generals as recently as the reign of\nAnastasius.2!*\n\nAt first glance, the celebration of a triumph by Caesar Tiberius\nin the reign of Justin [l appears related to the kind of development\nsignaled by Belisarius’ parade. Yet this\naspect of public life cannot be ignored. Prayer for the emperor was\nof course common to province and capital alike. In the provinces,\nhowever, the absence of the imperial court's constant pageantry,\nof the physical immediacy of its ceremonies and personnel, lent\npublic prayer a greater part in shaping the subjects’ conception of\ntheir ruler and his activities.             "result": "Frankish victory celebrations\n\nof royal authority like Charlemagne’s lead seal, as well perhaps as\nthat of his namesake, propagated the idea of royal victory in\nhexameter form: ‘Let there be glory for Christ and victory for\nking Charles!\"'#\n\nThe ideology of royal victory spilled over into the ruler’s\nceremonial life, most notably the royal investiture. Charles the\nBald’s coronation as ruler of the regnum Lotharii at Metz on\n9 September 869 is one of the rare instances for which there is\na detailed and reliable description.'®* After the unction and\ncrowning, the bishops handed the king a palm branch and a royal\nscepter. The accompanying prayer expounded the palm’s message\nof victory on earth and in heaven.**4 That the palm was placed on\nthe same ceremonial level as the royal scepter emphasizes the role\nof victory in the Carolingian idea of the ruler.18* Alcuin had\nreferred to palm branches in his allusion to a triumphal welcome\nfor Charlemagne and, in keeping with late antique tradition, that\nking had been welcomed into Rome by children waving palm\nbranches, during the final campaign against the Lombards. But\nmore recent developments helped place the palm in Charles the\nBald’s hand. Ninth-century popes had been sending palm bran-\nches to Frankish kings at least since 8§3.'!8* The branch was\nprobably mcant to be carried by the ruler in the palace liturgy's\nPalm Sunday procession, and the papal letters accompanying the\npalms emphasize their symbolism of both ethical and military\ntriumph.'*®?             "result": "The cult of St. Demetrius of Thessaloniki in the history of Byzantine-Slav relations B\n\nshall see, the cities of Trnovo in Bulgaria and Vladimir in Russia’; and pre-\neminently, of course, Thessaloniki itself. Early in the Middle Ages, its basilica\nof St. Demetrius became an object of pilgrimage for the whole East Christian\nworld. Some of the Slav pilgrims, whose writings have survived, display in their\ndescriptions of this church almost the same open-eyed wonder and religious\nawe which they reveal in their accounts of the sanctuaries of the Holy Land\nand Constantinople*. In no small measure was this veneration due to the holy\nmyron, which was believed to flow from the saint’s relics, and samples of which,\nendowed with therapeutic and apotropaic powers, were taken back by these\npilgrims to their homelands. Within the basilica, they offered their homage\nand prayers to St. Demetrius in front of the silver hexagonal ciborium, with\nsix columns supporting a dome, standing on the left side of the central nave\nand which popular piety regarded as the place of the saint’s tomb’.\n\nThe earliest unambiguous evidence of the veneration of St. Demetrius\nin Slavonic lands comes from the late ninth century. In the Macedonian prov-\nince of Bulgaria, at the turn of the century, the leading disciple of Cyril and\nMethodius, St. Clement of Ohrid, wrote an encomium for his feast. It is a\nsomewhat conventional and undistinguished work; yet it is noteworthy as the\nearliest non-liturgical text composed in the saint’s honour in the Old Church\nSlavonic language. Clement describes him as «the most glorious martyr» and\nas «the firm foundation of his fatherland»*.\n\nBatkanlinder, Sitzungsberichte der Kaiserlichen Akademie der Wissenschaften, philosoph.-\nhist. Mit\nrein militärischen Mitteln war die Autorität des Kaisers nicht zu erschüttern.\nAuch Generäle vermochten eine Kaiserherrschaft nicht aus den Angeln zu\nheben. Die einzige Möglichkeit, zum mächtigsten Mann des Reiches zu werden,\nohne selbst nach dem Purpur zu greifen, bestand für sie, nicht anders als für\nRufinus oder Eutropios, in der Beherrschung des Systems von innen. Das aber\nhieß nichts anderes, als daß sie die Akzeptanzgruppen unter erschwerten Be-\ndingungen zu gewinnen hatten. Denn einmal mußten die Generäle die sozio-\npolitischen Gruppen der Hauptstadt in geduldigem Werben an sich binden,\nnicht anders, als es ein Kaiser tat. Zum anderen aber gab es den Kaiser ja auch\nnoch: Seine Autorität als Herrscher und als oberster Patron war nicht zu be-\nseitigen, solange er selbst nicht beseitigt wurde. Leon I. und Zenon (457-491)\n\n \n\nes nämlich kaum mehr einen Heermeister, der mit Aspar konkurrieren konnte.\nNicht nur Aspars Vater und Plinta waren bereits tot, auch Ariobindus, einer\nseiner beiden Mitstreiter gegen Attila, war gestorben, der andere, Arnigisclus,\nauf dem Schlachtfeld geblieben. Der Isaurier Zenon hatte offenes Aufbegehren\nder Einflußnahme am Hof vorgezogen. Apollonios, ein weiterer Magister mi-\nlitum praesentalis, war ein Vertrauter Zenons und deswegen jetzt kaum mehr\neinflußreich. Maximinus, der 450 gegen Zenon entsandt werden sollte, hatte\ndavor vielleicht nie ein militärisches Kommando innegehabt, in jedem Fall war\nes das erste bedeutende. Das könnte ein Hinweis darauf sein, daß Theodosius\ndie Generäle ausgingen. Freilich fehlte es nicht an bedeutenden zivilen Amts-\nträgern,’ und der dritte Magister militum praesentalis war ein Schwergewicht:\nAnatolios, Konsular, Patrizier und für lange Jahre Heermeister des Ostens.\nTrotzdem war Aspar im Sommer 450 derjenige Amtsträger, der die größte Er-\nfahrung besaß - über 25 Jahre in höchsten Positionen - und wahrscheinlich über\ndas meiste Prestige verfügte.‘ Jedenfalls konnte er einigen Einfluß geltend\nmachen, als Theodosius am 28. Juli 450 nach einem Sturz vom Pferd starb und\ndas Reich plötzlich ohne Kaiser war.\n\nAspar stand am Sterbebett. Daß die Quellen das ausdrücklich festhalten, ist\nein weiterer Hinweis auf seine Wichtigkeit. Anwesend war aber auch Pulcheria.\nSie war lange politisch kaltgestellt gewesen, doch Theodosius hinterließ keinen\nSohn, überhaupt gab es außer ihr in Konstantinopel kein Mitglied des Theo-\ndosianischen Hauses mehr. Ebenso machtbewußt wie allgemein respektiert,\nkam Pulcheria zweifellos ein wesentliches Wort bei der Klärung der Nachfolge\nzu. Doch es dauerte fast einen Monat, bis am 25. August 450 Markian zum\nNachfolger ausgerufen wurde. Was genau in der Zwischenzeit geschah, entzieht\nsich unserer Kenntnis, weil über die Sukzession hinter den Mauern des Palastes\nentschieden wurde. Die Dauer zeigt aber, daß es turbulent zugegangen sein\nmuß, und wir wissen auch, daß Aspar die andere entscheidende Stimme hatte:\nMarkian war sein Adjutant.             "result": "Aspar und das vergebliche Werben um Akzeptanz 521\n\n \n\nDiese drei Nachrichten, über die Zisterne, das Feuer und die Kirchenstif-\ntung, sind zufällig überliefert, Stücke eines Puzzles, von dem wir nicht einmal\nwissen, welchen Umfang es hat. Aber es ist doch interessant, daß es kein ein-\nziges Mal um Aspars Bindung zum Heer geht und daß auch die Beziehungen zu\nden übrigen Barbaren und Homöern nicht thematisiert werden. Höchstens\ndienten diese, im letzten Fall, als Basis, von der aus Aspar auf andere Akzep-\ntanzgruppen Konstantinopels einzuwirken versuchte. Popularität in der\nHauptstadt hielt er offenbar für sehr wichtig, wenn nicht entscheidend für Er-\nhalt und Ausbau seiner Stellung.\n\nEs ist hier nicht nötig, auf jedes Detail der Konfrontation zwischen Aspar\nund Leon einzugehen. Brian Croke hat in einem grundlegenden Aufsatz von\n2005 den Hergang überzeugend rekonstruiert und analysiert. Vor allem hat er\ngegen die gängige Sicht gezeigt, daß es sich bei den politischen Auseinander-\nsetzungen an Leons Hof nicht um eine ethnische Konfrontation zwischen einem\ngermanisch-alanischen Block um Aspar und den Isauriern unter dem späteren\nKaiser Zenon handelte. Es kämpften schlicht General gegen General, General\ngegen Kaiser, und der Preis war die Regelung von Leons Nachfolge.’ Crokes\nLeon ist weit aktiver als in älteren Darstellungen, in denen er die meiste Zeit ein\nbloßer Spielball der Interessen ist. Aber ich denke, man kann und muß in diese\nRichtung noch weitergehen. Auch bei Croke ist der Kaiser am Schluß über-\nwältigt und muß Aspars Sohn Patricius zum Caesar erheben. Leon I. und Zenon (457-491)\n\n \n\nVon dieser Strategie verabschiedeten sich Aspar und Ardabur jetzt abrupt,\n\njedenfalls wenn man der Darstellung bei Zonaras folgt: Schon bei seiner\n\nLeon mit Orest, vgl. nur Scnamp [2006]. z. St.), als Zeugnis für die Situation des Jahres\n470 ist sie aber wertlos, selbst wenn sie datiert und Aspar in dem Kapitel erwähnt wäre.\nNach der syrischen Vita von Symeon Stylites dem Älteren war zur Zeit von dessen Tod\n„Heerführer mit dem Oberbefehl über den ganzen Osten der General Ardabur, der\nSohn des Aspar, welche wie Könige geehrt wurden in ihren Gebieten“ (133 [= 125]).\nDiese Formulierung ist gewählt, um hervorzuheben, welch bedeutende Männer zur\nBeisetzung Symeons erschienen. Sie bezieht sich auf Symeons Tod im Jahr 459 (nicht\n469, wie Croxe schreibt), nicht auf Leons spätere Bemühungen um Reliquien. Mit der\nSituation von 470 hat die Stelle also nichts zu tun. Und auch an sich ist sie wenig\nspektakulär. Ardabur war damals ja Heermeister des Ostens, und natürlich wurde er als\nhöchster Repräsentant Roms im Osten besonders geehrt. Das gleiche ließ sich auf\nAspar übertragen, von dem der Verfasser wußte, daß er in Konstantinopel eine noch\nmächtigere Position bekleidete. Daß die beiden aber kaisergleich gewesen seien, ist\nnicht impliziert. Gemeint ist ihre begrenzte Amtsautorität: „in ihren Gebieter\nritte Beleg stammt aus dem Leben des Marcellus, des Abtes des Akoimetenklosters:\nArdabur und Aspar hätten tun können, was sie wollten, der Kaiser wollte sie gern daran\nhindern, aber wagte es nicht (vita Mare. 32). Diese Bemerkung kommt in einer Sektion\njer Vita, in der es um Marcellus’ Mitleid gegen die Niedrigen und seine Standfestigkeit\ngegen die Hohen geht. Je mächtiger also Ardabur, desto beeindruckender die Leistung\nes Helden. Tatsächlich vermögen die zwei zum Beweis angebotenen Geschichten die\nBehauptung nicht zu bestätigen. Die eine betrifft Marcellus’ Widerstand gegen Patri-\ncius’ Erhebung zum Caesar, worauf ich gleich im Text eingehen werde. In der anderen\nflieht ein gewisser Johannes vor Ardabur in Marcellus‘ Kloster. Auf dessen Bitten und\nDrohungen hin gibt der Abt nicht nach, schließlich schickt Ardabur Soldaten, die Jo-\nhannes zur Not mit Gewalt holen sollen. Doch ein wundersames Himmelszeichen bringt\nie Soldaten zum Abzug, Ardabur billigt dieses Verhalten und verzeiht Johannes. Diese\nvage Anekdote illustriert einen Zustand des gesellschaftlichen Lebens, den man be-\nauern kann, der aber nichtsdestotrotz üblich war: daß mächtige einzelne ihren Willen\nzur Not mit Gewalt durchsetzen konnten. Außerhalb der Städte mit ihrer Konzentration\nvon Volk und Amtsträgern war das natürlich einfacher, und tatsächlich lag das Akoi-\nmetenkloster auf der asiatischen Seite des Bosporos. Für Ardabur als hohen Offizier\nwar ein solches Vorgehen natürlich besonders einfach, die Soldaten gehörten wahr-\nscheinlich zu seinem regulären militärischen Gefolge. Über Johannes’ Identität weiß die\nVita nichts zu sagen, was doch wohl heißt, daß er sozial unbedeutend war. Deswegen\nkonnte er keine Hilfe vom Kaiser erwarten, nicht weil dieser sie ihm nicht zu gewähren\nwagte. Auch Johannes’ Vergehen bleibt im dunkeln. Weder versuchte Marcellus darüber\nmit Ardabur zu rechten, noch appellierte er selbst an die weltlichen oder geistlichen\nAutoritäten, obwohl ihm dies ohne weiteres möglich gewesen wäre. Das mag der Vita\ngeschuldet sein, die Marcellus hier als furchtlosen Einzelkämpfer zeichnet, aber ebenso\nkann es ein Hinweis darauf sein, daß Ardaburs Vorgehen gegen Johannes gesell-\nschaftlich akzeptiert war, ja vielleicht handelte Ardabur sogar als Amtsträger gegenüber\neinem Delinquenten, einem Deserteur oder Befehlsverweigerer etwa. Auf keinen Fall\nerscheint Ardabur hier als ‘allmächtig’ - dafür aber als guter Christ. Trotz einer bemüht\nübelwollenden Interpretation des Autors kommt das schnelle Einlenken eines derarti-\ngen Wüterichs für den Leser überraschend. Ardabur wußte sehr wohl, was er seinem\nGlauben und seiner öffentlichen Stellung schuldig war, und so gab er im rechten Mo-\nment nach.\n\n \n\n \n\n \n\n \n\n \n\n   \n\n \n\n \n\n \n\n \n\n \n\n \n\n \n\nBereitgestellt von | Universität Wie\nAngermeld\nHeruntergeladen am | 04.01.20 182\n\n   \n  \n\n \n\f"

Leon I. und Zenon (457-491)\n\n \n\nZenon eigens mit dem Kampf gegen Theoderich betraut worden und dürfte\nwenigstens Comes, wenn nicht neuer Heermeister für Thrakien gewesen sein.\nAlexander Demandt folgerte aus Basiliskos’ Heermeisteramt, daß dieser dem\nKaiser militärisch überlegen gewesen sei und Zenon ohne Schwierigkeiten aus\nder Stadt geworfen habe.” Doch keine Quelle bezeugt dies. Selbst Basiliskos\ntrat als offen Handelnder erst nach Zenons Flucht auf. Das Heer hatte keinen\nAnteil an dem Umsturz, die aufrührerischen Feldherren setzten ihre Armeen\ngar nicht ein. Wie auch? Die Untätigkeit ist nur ein weiterer eindrucksvoller\nBeleg dafür, daß das hauptstädtische Kaisertum dem Zugriff des Feldheeres\nentzogen war.\n\nAuch die Geistlichkeit scheint keine Rolle gespielt zu haben, weder Bischof\nAkakios noch die Mönche noch Heilige Männer, ebensowenig das Volk. Das\nmacht diese Usurpation zur einzigen, die ohne öffentliche Beteiligung auskam\nund dennoch gelang. Bei jedem anderen versuchten oder gelungenen Umsturz\nin Konstantinopel war in irgendeiner Weise das Volk involviert. Nicht hier.\nZenon war ja im Hippodrom und sah einem Wagenrennen zu, als Verina ihn\nrief. Der Kaiser sah offenbar kein Problem darin, sich für einige Zeit vom\ngemeinschaftsstiftenden Spektakel zurückzuziehen. Hätte es Unmutsbekun-\ndungen im Hippodrom gegeben, hätte Johannes von Antiocheia sie an dieser\nStelle erwähnen können. Aber es gab offenbar keine. Zenons Flucht wird da-\ndurch nur rätselhafter.\n\nImmerhin lassen sich ein paar Faktoren benennen, die Zenons noch junge\nRegierung belasteten, und zwar deshalb, weil sie den Kaiser zumindest poten-\ntiell unbeliebt machten. Das Henotikon lag noch in der Zukunft, aber es war\nschon zu Lebzeiten Leons klargeworden, daß Zenon nicht unbedingt eine or-\nthodoxe Kirchenpolitik betrieb. Während seiner Amtszeit als Heermeister des\nOstens hatte er in Antiocheia antichalkedonische Agitation gebilligt und den\nMönch Petros den Walker auf den Bischofsstuhl gehievt. Leon hatte damals\n\n \n\n \n\n \n\nStrabo gegen Leon kämpfen zu lassen, und tatsächlich bezeugt Malchos, daß Strabo\ngemeinsam mit Armatus gegen die Thraker vorging. Die Stelle stammt aber aus einer\nspäteren Rede Zenons an seine Soldaten, in der er vor einem erneuten Waffengang mit\nStrabo dessen Untaten rekapitulierte. Dazu paßte eine Kooperation mit dem inzwischen\nhingerichteten Armatus gut. Entscheidend aber ist: Nicht einmal in diesem feindseligen\nKontext sagt oder impliziert Malchos, daß Strabo damals im Aufstand gegen die Re-\ngierung gestanden habe. Vielmehr operierte Armatus zusammen mit Strabo in Leons\nAuftrag, „presumabiy after the peace with Theoderic Strabo at the end of the reign“\n(BiockLey [1983], 458 Anm. 25).\n\n52 Demanpr (1970), 778. Ve-\nrina war ein Mitglied der kaiserlichen Familie, eine Augusta, die Witwe Leons,\ndie Mutter seiner Frau Artadne. Sie einem Untergebenen aushändigen zu\nmüssen, ohne selbst überhaupt die Gelegenheit zu einer Reglementierung zu\nbekommen, war ein ungeheurer Gesichtsverlust.\n\nIlus war der wichtigste Mann am Hof. In den kirchenpolitischen Ausein-\nandersetzungen wurde seine Unterstützung gesucht, obwohl er sich gar nicht\nselbst in diesen Fragen profilierte. Theoderich Strabo sah ihn als einen bedeu-\ntenden und vertrauenswürdigen Partner an.” Illus tat sich als Bauherr in der\nStadt hervor, wie er sich dort überhaupt durch Großzügigkeit und Gerechtigkeit\nprofiliert haben soll (diese knappe Bemerkung bei Candidus hätten wir gern ein\nbißchen ausführlicher). Ebenso beeindruckte er durch seine Tapferkeit im\nKrieg. Er war Zenons Feldherr nach Wahl, als eine Eskalation mit den Goten\ndrohte, obwohl er gar kein Heermeister war, und später, 481, deckte er die Stadt\ngegen den anmarschierenden Strabo. Die Wertschätzung seiner militärischen\nFähigkeiten liefert auch den einzigen plausiblen Grund für seine eilige Rück-\nberufung nach dem Erdbeben. Eigentlich konnte es Zenon nur recht sein, wenn\nWlus seine Zeit in Isaurien verlängerte, und die Beseitigung von Erdbebenfolgen\nwar eine Aufgabe für den Stadt- und für den Prätorianerpräfekten, nicht für den\nMagister officiorum. Aber das Beben hatte Teile der Stadtmauer und viele\nTürme zum Einsturz gebracht, und Zenon fürchtete wahrscheinlich, nicht zu\nUnrecht, eine gotische Attacke auf die nun unbefestigte Stadt. Nur Ilus schien\nfähig, diese Situation zu bewältigen, und so holte ihn Zenon zurück, nur um\ngleich darauf von ihm gedemütigt zu werden.”\n\nZwischenspiel: Markians Putsch (479)\n\nDer Auftritt vor Chalkedon brachte IHus auf den Gipfel seiner Macht. This is attested in the seventh-century Visigothic Formulae by the\normula: ingenuum te civem Romanum esse constituo.*’ The Formulae Arvernenses list\nhe advantages that people manumitted to become Roman citizens had, mainly in\nhe freedom of drawing up a will.°* The seventh-century Frankish Lex Ribuaria offers\nhree procedures of manumission, one of which, the ritual of the ‘open doors’, result-\ned in Roman citizenship, now a ‘medium status of limited freedom’. This was also\nhe only option to live under Roman law. Manumission in church, although explicitly\nstated as conforming fo Roman law, did not confer Romanness any more: it made the\nreedman a dependent of an ecclesiastic institution — which seems to be an innova-\n\n \n\nion of the Ribuarian Code. The most favourable option now was manumission by\n‘penny-throw’ in the presence of the king, which made a free Ribuarian. Options\n\n \n\nmay have been reduced, but one could still become Roman in the regna. The practice\nof manumission to become a Roman citizen was also continued in Byzantine Italy, as\nis attested by a document from Bari in which a slave is freed to become a polités R6-\nmaion, cited in the contribution by Annick Peters-Custot.®° An indirect reflection of a\ncontinuing idea of citizenship may perhaps be found in the name of the modern\nWelsh for themselves, Cymry, which could be derived from ‘fellow citizens’.\nRoman law continued to be applied, and remained more important in the early\n\n \n\nmedieval West than we tend to believe, as is also attested by a considerable manu-\nscript transmission. Sane quicumque hic latini sunt, id est qui nec siriste nec graece\nnouerunt, ne contristentur, et ipsis exponitur eis, quia sunt alii fratres et sorores graecolatini,\nqui latine exponunt eis.*\n\nHer account is all the more remarkable because it allows the interpretation that, in\nOriens, Greek was already in the late fourth century the dominant language in the\nchurch. Greek represented the Christian cultural identity of the educated classes.\nBut although in the early Byzantine period only a minority of the eastern Roman\nEmpire’s population were native Latin speakers, a conscious and active political\nidentification with romanitas required until the era of Justinian’s reign at least a\nasic knowledge of Latin.” Latin was the language of the emperor, the army, the\nlaw, and the administration. From the sixth century onwards romanitas lost its lin-\nguistic significance, but remained the supreme political principle. It was plainly\nropagated by the emperor and the authorities of the state and the church. Romani-\ntas formed the basis for the at times changing political homogeneity of the empire\nand for the Byzantine sense of cultural superiority within the European — or better\nEuromediterranean — ecumene, though with a growing separation from latinitas.\nSeparation began with the simple loss of the knowledge of Latin, and continued\nwith the growing antipathies on both sides, which became more and more evident\nrom the ninth century onwards.\n\n \n\n \n\n \n\n \n\nThe Emperor Justinian\n\nOn the occasion of the publication of his early novellae the Emperor Justinian ex-\nplained why he published them in two languages, in Latin and Greek,” though it\nseems to be evident, that he (and his advisers in legislative matters, above all Tribo-\nnianus) would have preferred Latin to Greek. He called Latin ‘our from the fathers\ninherited language’, in contrast to ‘the language of the Greeks’ or ‘the common\nGreek language’. Firstly, as already in the period\nafter 212, this would have happened in most cases at birth. In the regions of Southern\n\n \n\nGaul, for instance, a child would most likely be born from two Roman parents\nand thus live according to Roman law, too. Consequently, these Romans, despite\neing defined as citizens in a legal sense, could in some ways regard themselves\nas being a community of descent - remnants of a culture that once had claimed\no be a universal one, but meanwhile had become provincial and was now faced\n\n \n\nwith neighbours, friends and even relatives with a different legal background. In\ncases of mixed Roman-barbarian marriages, however, we may assume that according\no gender and status of their parents children would be born either as Romans or as\n\n \n\narbarians in a legal sense. As already becomes evident here, ‘Romanness’ was not\n\n \n\nsimply a question of the continuity of a Roman provincial population under barbar-\nian rule. Quite the contrary, the very existence of barbarian law codes in Gaul would\nhave an impact on the definition of the legal status of an individual, even if one did\n\n \n\nnot regard oneself as a barbarian. The place of birth mattered too, as we shall see\nlater.\n\nA second way of becoming a Roman was by manumission. In pest-Roman Gaul,\nhowever, there were different ways of manumitting a slave with divergent effects.             "result": "434 === Katharina Winckler\n\ncharters and disappeared afterwards.*°* The Rottachgau fragment was listed as part\nof the property held by Passau in the Rottachgau, meaning that the scribe still knew\nwhere the donated land was located, although the place name noted was in its Latin/\nRomance form: vicus Fonaluae. Today this knowledge is lost and we do not know any-\nmore which village was meant. Probably the Roman name was soon replaced by the\nGerman form Weissenbrunn (= fons albus), a quite frequent toponym.’°?\n\nAbove we learned that the Bavarian Quarti(nus) of Vipitenum/Sterzing called\nhimself in 828 a ‘Norican’, though he probably did not use that word as a synonym\nfor ‘Bavarian’. Presumably he took the name of his home-valley that was cailed\nNurihtal/vallis Noricana in his time and afterwards.‘*° Already in Venantius Fortuna-\ntus’ Life of St. Martin of the mid-sixth century the Pustertal is regarded as Norican\nsoil. We know of a Roman toll station at Klausen near Saben, therefore the border\nbetween Noricum and Italy (Venetia et Histria) was probably located exactly here\nin late antiquity. But regardless of which Roman province the region had belonged\nto, between the eighth and thirteenth centuries it formed a defined area, within\nwhich the ancient name of the Roman Province Noricum could live on. One can sup-\npose by the self-designation of Quartinus that his ‘Norican’ identity in a Bavarian\ncontext was important to note. Yet we cannot tell, if it was a sign of remembering\n\nthe Roman Empire or, on the contrary, a reminiscence of the late antique reflexes\n412\n\n \n\nagainst it by emphasizing a local identity.\nWe find further evidence for roman space ‘gone wild’ in Arbeo’s Vita Corbiniani\nof the mid-eighth century, still written in a Merovingian-style Latin: a finibus Valerie\natque Noricensis Cisalpina in caput Italie. Valeria used to be a roman province ei-\nther in eastern Pannonia or in the middle of the Italian peninsula. Attempts have\nbeen made to link the Bavarian past to the pannonian Valeria,\" but it seems to\nmake more sense to read Arbeo’s expression as a learned attempt to Latinize/Roman-\nize terms like Wualhogoi or Uualhum,'® which in turn would hint towards the multi-\nlayered identities of early medieval Bavaria.
