            "result": "SOCIAL CONTEXTS 183\n\nbut was never made a formal requirement, nor was punishment threatened\nfor its neglect.\n\nBISHOPS OF CURIAL BACKGROUND\n\nMost bishops in late antiquity came from the municipal elite in the cities of\nthe Roman Empire: the curiales.5| These were landowning families, who\npassed their status on to their heirs along with their property. Their curial sta-\ntus was considered an honor, but this honor came at a price. The curialis was\nexpected to be eligible and willing to run for municipal office, which involved\ngreat personal expense: the provision of games and entertainments, the\nheating of the baths, going on embassies. Personal status and honor were also\ndisplayed and reinforced through the tradition of private euergeteia in the\nform of building activity and other benefactions to the city. Moreover, i in addi-\ntion to the taxes each curialis had to pay on his own property, the curia col-\nlectively was held responsible for the collection of the tax money of the city\nand its territory in the amount that had been assessed by agents of the fisc.”\n\nThe Christianization of the curiales had proceeded at a particularly rapid\npace in the course of the third and fourth centuries. During the persecu-\ntions of the second and third centuries, individual Christians were some-\ntimes identified as being of curial or otherwise privileged status in the mar-\ntyrs’ Acta. This is particularly evident in North Africa and in the papyrus\ndocumentation from Egypt. In Asia Minor entire cities were known to be\nChristian already in the pre-Constantinian period, one example being the\n(unnamed) city whose inhabitants, including the magistrates, were rounded\nup and burned in the Great Persecution. After the end of the persecutions,\ncities with a Christian curia seized the opportunity to apply for favors to the\nemperor Constantine, whom they knew to be a coreligionist. This argument\nwas successful in securing the rank of a civitas for the town of Orcistus in\nPhrygia Salutaris in 324-326,\" and in the elevation of the town of Maiouma\n\n \n\n62. D. We have several accounts of such acclamatory assent by municipal legislative\nbodies. An excerpt from the proceedings of the city council at Tyre in 174 includes the\nacclamatory formulae by which the councillors indicated their assent, epephonésan;* a\ndecree of the early third century from Mylasa ends with a fragmentary record of the\nacclamations at a public assembly in Greek, but introduced by the Latin term ‘ succlam(atum)\nest’ ;? fragments from a similar document, including the word ‘ suclam[atum ’, were found\nat Pisidian Antioch ;* a decree from Chalcis, of the third century, is interspersed with the\nassenting acclamations of the councillors—synedroi—and of the people, introduced by\neb(oésan), eb(oése) ;° and the acclamations of a public meeting at Oxyrhynchus in about 300\nare recorded in full in a papyrus.?° Private fraternities also used acclamations in this way ;\na record of the proceedings of the Athenian Iobacchi in 178 includes their assenting\nacclamations, introduced by ex(eboésan),.4 By the mid fourth century it appears to be\nestablished practice for church councils to approve proposals by acclamation; thus, for\nexample, several canons of the Council of Serdica of 343 are put forward with the final\nphrase, ‘ Si hoc omnibus placet ’, followed by the response, ‘ Synodus respondit : Placet ’.1?\nIt has in the past been argued that, during the second century, the Senate came increasingly\nto indicate assent by acclamation; but it has recently been demonstrated that there is very\nlittle solid evidence for such a development up to the mid third century.\" After that date\nthere is very little reliable evidence for senatorial procedure; but the Gesta Senatus of 438\nrecord the approval of the Theodosian Code by the Roman Senate with cries of ‘ Placet ’\nas well as more complex acclamations.14\n\nThe most widely attested function of acclamations, which can be derived partly from\nreligious and. partly from legislative practice, is that properly described as acclamation—the\nhonouring of an individual. The simplest form of such acclamations gives a man a particular\nepithet, just as in the formulae honouring the gods—so-and-so is great, or good, or patriotic,\nphilopatris; it can be shown how such acclamations by public assemblies underlie the\nterminology of the abundant decrees with which the cities of the Greek East honoured\nprominent citizens? At Rome, the most obvious example of a title bestowed by acclamation\nis that of Imperator, granted by conclamatio.'® It is clear that a whole range of epithets came\nto be so used; thus Livy could conceive of Camillus being acclaimed at his triumph as\n‘Romulus ac parens patriae, conditorque ’.17\n\nAbove all, such acclamations were used to honour rulers; and acclamation increased\nsteadily in importance as part of the ceremonial surrounding Roman emperors.'® It is clear\nthat by the first century a.p. the practice was already well and widely established. More explicitly, John,\npatriarch of Constantinople, in his letter covering the acclamations of the crowd there in 518,\nsaid: Qeia tis ovpavedev yéyove kivnois Tod piAoypiotou Adou.7? When Severus, the\nmonophysite leader, was acclaimed at Antioch in 512 by everyone—dotep eK évos\norouertos (compare Chrysostom, above)—this unanimity was recognized as a ‘ manifest\nsign’ of the divine purpose.”3\n\nThe idea that unanimous acclamations are more than just an expression of opinion,\nbut have a divinely inspired authority, is ancient, and may relate to the use of acclamations\nin religious ceremonies (as discussed above). Peterson drew attention to the regular references\nto acclamations in response to miracles, both pagan and Christian.”4 It is as manifestations\nof a divine impulse, as well as of public opinion, that acclamations are significant ; and this\nis most important of all in the validation of the authority of leaders, both secular and\necclesiastical. Thus Eusebius describes the election of a third-century pope, Fabian:\ntov trévTa Aadv doen Up’ Evds Trvesparos Belov KivnSévTa, TEOOUBPIg TéoD Kal Lie WuYh,\n‘ &€iov ’ ériBofioai.”® By the fourth century, acclamations had an established part in the\nelection of bishops.?* The steady increase in the acclaiming of Roman emperors has been\ntouched on (above, p. 182); already under Trajan Pliny found it appropriate to dwell at\nsome length in his Panegyric on an account of the Senate’s acclamations for Trajan, with the\nobservation: ‘ multa fecimus sponte, plura instinctu quodam et imperio’.7? By the later\nfifth century, the accounts in the De Ceremontis suggest that popular acclamation at\nConstantinople regularly formed part of the ceremonial of declaring a new emperor (above,\nn. 36); and in the Christian Empires of East and West such acclamations could be seen as\nreflecting the popular acclamation of the ancient Kings of Israel.’® It was this function of\nacclamations, as validating and reinforcing authority, which survived into the mediaeval\nperiod, when their role in expressing public opinions and requests had atrophied.?°\n\nIt seems that it is this function of acclamations which came to be increasingly respected,\nparticularly as the traditional institutions for the expression and conveying of power fell into\ndisuse. It is entirely appropriate that a panegyric, such as Pliny’s, should attribute importance\nto acclamations ; both are part of a new relationship between ruler and ruled, outside the\nold institutions. When the honours accorded to a benefactor, or an emperor, come to be\ninscribed in the acclamatory formulae used by an assembly, this suggests the decreasing\nrelevance of the intermediate authorities who would in the past have translated the expression\nof such honours into the traditional language of an honorific decree or dedication. Before\nconsidering the implications of this more fully (Section rv), it will be helpful to consider\nthe structure of acclamations (Section 1), and against this background, the new set of\nacclamations from Aphrodisias (Section 11).\n\nII, The structure of acclamations\nFrom all the evidence discussed above it is possible to get a very good idea of the rules\n\ngoverning the structure of individual acclamations, and their ordering and use.             "result": "The Christian Middle Ages 543\n\nAnglo-Saxon, for instance, did not include a word for parish (“priest-shire”\nreferred to the area of a priest’s rule or responsibility), but “parish” in Middle\nEnglish, almost from the beginning and certainly by the thirteenth century, could\nrefer indiscriminately to village and church.33 So, too, in French, the local\ncommune (in recent studies treated as the encadrement of the countryside and folk)\nwas most commonly known before the Revolution as the “parish.” The village\ncommunity found its identity in its “parish.”\n\nAt the heart of parish life were its rituals. Synodical statutes reveal not only the\npractices normative for Christian observance but also, by implication and some-\ntimes explicitly, the transgressions of that norm. Visitation records disclose what\nmatters bishops, archdeacons, and their associates thought most in need of\ncorrection. Liturgical sources, though much harder for historians to deal with, are\nequally important. The real measure of Christian religious culture on a broad scale\nmust be the degree to which time, space, and ritual observances came to be defined\nand grasped essentially in terms of the Christian liturgical year. Carolingian\nlegislation placed great emphasis on Sunday as a required day of rest, thus\npunctuating the “secular” week and drawing attention to religious obligations.\nAfter the year 1200 or so, and much earlier in some instances, ordinary legal and\nadministrative documents were routinely dated in terms of the appropriate saints’\nday or feast day. Of those rituals that touched each individual in the parish\npersonally, the Christianization of birth and death seems to have proceeded\nrapidly in the ceremonies surrounding “christening” and “last rites.”84+ Marriage,\nhowever, was not brought literally into the church and before the altar until the\nend of the Middle Ages, though Christian guidelines began to transform that\ninstitution in the ninth century and its sacramentality was established in the twelfth.\nThe result, typically, was an overlay of Christian and other notions of marriage,\nbut to imagine wholly separate and distinct conceptions of marriage competing\nover centuries is an exaggeration.® Similarly, private confession, which originated\nin the monastery, only gradually became a ritual practiced in the country parish,\na routine rather than an extraordinary event required annually of every Christian\nafter 1215. In the High Middle Ages it became the chief means of personal\nreligious formation, chiefly by examining each individual against a standardized\nlist of vices and virtues; even Dominican preaching aimed ultimately at bringing\nsouls to confession.             "result": "MONARCHY AND MASS COMMUNICATION: ANTIOCH A.D. 362/3 REVISITED 167\n\ndistorting mirrors of reality, the degree to which this is the case deserves further attention,\nespecially the conscious attempts by their authors to steer the interpretation of events. Both\nissues closely interlock: as the failure to communicate created a bad impression of the\nemperor, the Misopogon was an attempt to overturn that negative image. Libanius, in\nturn, closely engages with the image created of both Antioch and Julian himself in the\nMisopogon. Self-presentation and re-presentation are for them more important than\nfactual reporting. This paper, therefore, proposes a re-appraisal both of the events\nthemselves and of our main sources for them.\n\nJulian’s Misopogon is a long, satirical, self-deprecating literary document written by an\nemperor, and was supposedly displayed on one of Antioch’s main monuments.! Many\nscholars have emphasized, and tried to explain, the extraordinary and almost aberrant\nnature of this text. Julian’s omnipresent self-ridicule, for example, has invited\npsychological readings, which have detected the emperor’s frustrations, or, as some have\nconcluded, his labile mental state.2 Others have read the events in Antioch as the result\nof an inevitable clash of ideological oppositions between a largely Christian city and the\nadvocate of pagan restoration.?\n\nMore recently, such psychological explanations have mostly been abandoned in favour of\nmore contextualized readings of the text. Hans-Ulrich Wiemer, for example, reads the\nMisopogon within the economic context of the food shortage in Antioch in A.p. 362/3,\nwhich troubled the relationship between Julian and the city. Maud Gleason, on the other\nhand, focuses on the text’s socio-cultural context: with reference to Libanius’ Oration\n16.35,° she reads the Misopogon as a ‘festive satire’, a good-humoured text written in\nresponse to Antiochene insults during the New Year festival, and, she claims, originally\ninterpreted as such: if the Antiochenes may have overstepped the festive licence a bit,\nJulian’s response was itself part of that festive atmosphere and fits, moreover, into a\npattern of imperial ‘edicts of chastisement’, with which emperors reacted to popular\nattacks. There is, therefore, nothing extraordinary about the Misopogon.             "result": "168 LIEVE VAN HOOF and PETER VAN NUFFELEN\n\nGleason’s article has been of critical importance in helping scholarship situate the\nMisopogon in the context of public ceremonial. It provides the starting point for the\npresent article, although our interpretation differs from hers. Gleason concluded that the\nMisopogon was a ‘““normal” or traditional’ (107) example of either a ‘festive satire’ or\nan ‘edict of chastisement’. There is, indeed, an unresolved tension in the article between\nthe first half, which sees the Misopogon as a festive satire, a good-humoured reply that\nwas part of the New Year festivities as much as the insults, and the second half, which\nreads it as an edict of chastisement and thus not linked to the carnivalesque atmosphere\nof the New Year festival. The first half of Gleason’s argument, the suggestion of an\n(exclusive) link with the New Year festival, cannot be maintained. As far as the insults\nof the Antiochenes are concerned, there is clear evidence that they were not punctual\nbut continuous and circulating long before New Year a.p. 363: all our sources agree\nthat the insults went on during the entire period of Julian’s residence in Antioch.”\nNeither can the Misopogon be fruitfully seen as part of the New Year licence: it was\npublished after 18 January at the very earliest, ie. more than two weeks after the end of\nthe festival, and, as will be demonstrated below, probably considerably later, which\nmakes it hard to see why its original readers would have understood it as a festive satire\nwithin the context of the festival.\n\nThe link with edicts of chastisement, proposed in the second part of Gleason’s article, is a\nmuch more fruitful suggestion in our view, in that it singles out public communication\nbetween ruler and subject as the key context in which to understand the Misopogon. We\nshall pursue this avenue of thought, but in a different direction: whilst it is true that the\nMisopogon shares many characteristics with edicts of chastisement, we do not think that\nthis turns the text into a normal response by a late antique emperor. Gleason suggests that\nthe Misopogon ‘seems not to have shocked Julian’s contemporaries as it shocks us’ (107),\nas it was just one amongst many imperial edicts of chastisement, which, moreover,\n‘preserved his own reputation for clemency’ (118-19). This interpretation does not, in our\nview, fully take into account contemporary receptions of the text: pagan and Christian\nauthors alike were struck by the Misopogon so much as to discuss it, and many of them\npointed out that anger shimmers through.’ Indeed, as Gleason herself shows, edicts of\nchastisement were not always good-humoured (116-17). Moreover, seeing the Misopogon\nas just one more example of such an edict does not do justice to the peculiar nature of the\ntext. As we shall argue, the Misopogon is actually a massive reply after a long period of\nsilence, not just a brief edict of chastisement but a conscious attempt to impose Julian’s\ninterpretation of events after a long failure to communicate as the people of Antioch\nexpected. As such it stands out among the known instances of edicts of chastisement.\n\nWhilst taking its initial cue from Gleason’s 1986 article, the present contribution thus\nfocuses more centrally on ritualized communication and its possible failure, and includes\nthe earliest reception of the Misopogon. Both elements contribute to a new\ninterpretation of the text. Section u sets out how ritualized communication usually\nfunctioned in Late Antiquity and Section m how the events of a.p. 362/3 led to a\nshort-circuit in the communication between emperor and subjects. The Misopogon is Julian’s conscious attempt to\nredirect and reshape the interpretation of what was a failure of ritualized\ncommunication on his part: his rhetoric invites the reader to see the events as an\ninevitable clash of ideological oppositions, and the Misopogon itself as a\ngood-humoured text (Section Iv). Literary as well as epigraphic evidence suggests that\npublic shouts of approval became much more frequent in the later Empire!+ — or at least\nthat they were much more frequently recorded, which suggests that an increased\nimportance was attached to them. In a recent paper that sums up earlier research, H.-U.\nWiemer argues that acclamations must be understood as public shouts of loyalty for the\nemperor. He suggests that the emperor staged the performance of acclamations\nthroughout the Empire so as to be assured of the continuous support of his subjects.15\nSuch an interpretation, focused on mere expressions of loyalty voiced by a claque,\nreduces acclamations to staged and static phenomena.\n\nYet public appearances, however well staged they may be, are always prone to\nunexpected interruptions by petitioners or public outcry, or, conversely, by a lack of\nenthusiasm and approval.!6 In many cases, acclamations, therefore, appear as\nimprovised and dynamic phenomena that are part of wider events. A clear example can\nbe found in the Church History of Sozomen (fl. c. A.D. 439-450), who records how a\npopular riot persuaded the emperor Arcadius to recall John Chrysostom after his first\nexile in A.D. 403. Notwithstanding strong popular support in the streets, John had\nobeyed the order to leave for exile so as to avoid the accusation of stirring up the\nmasses. When the people got vent of this, they ‘rioted and insulted the emperor, the\nsynod, Theophilus, and Severian’. When the latter, a sworn enemy of John, preached a\nsermon that approved of John’s exile, ‘the people turned mad, renewed their anger and\nrioted in the extreme’: they went to the imperial palace and requested the return of\nJohn. ‘Yielding to the demands of the people, the empress persuaded her husband to\nagree’ and John was recalled. The people received him with chants and acclamations;\nafter a sermon in which John praised the imperial couple, the people also addressed\nacclamations to them (8.18). Far from being staged shouts of loyalty, acclamations\nappear from this episode as improvised expressions of popular approval as well as\ndissent.!? They are, moreover, not static, unidirectional statements, but highly dynamic\nevents: whilst the people persuade the empress to recall John, John persuades the people\nto change their opinion about the emperor. As such, they are not limited to one\nparticular occasion, but play a key rdle throughout the sequence of events described by\nSozomen.             "result": "72 LIEVE VAN HOOF and PETER VAN NUFFELEN\n\nand communicating with the populace. It is here that things went wrong for Julian in\nAntioch,\n\nHi THE CRISIS OF A.D. 362/3 AS A CRISIS OF COMMUNICATION\n\nThe events of A.p. 362/3 in Antioch have often been reduced to a Versorgungskrise: an\neconomic crisis which can stand model for many other such crises in the Later Roman\nEmpire?” The main grievance of the population may indeed have been that Julian had\nnot taken sufficient measures to alleviate two successive bad harvests. But such an\nemphasis on the economic background risks over-estimating the extent of the crisis. The\nsources state explicitly that Julian’s interventions regarding market prices were\nunnecessary.2® What Antioch faced in A.D. 362/3 was not a famine but a food shortage:\nnot a critical shortage leading to widespread starvation but a short-term scarcity.2?\nMoreover, as far as Julian’s dealings with the Antiochenes are concerned, contemporary\nsources pay more attention to another aspect of the crisis: communication. Indeed, the\nfood shortage is not the main issue in the Misopogon: only towards its end (368c) does\nJulian come to talk about his handling of market shortages as one of the causes of the\nconflict with the Antiochenes, and even there the emphasis is on how he and the\nAntiochenes communicated. Likewise, in Oration 16 Libanius spends more effort\ndiscussing the Antiochene insults of Julian (16.28-38) than the market shortage (16.21-\n7), and even when the latter is discussed, the emphasis is explicitly not on the actions\nbut on the attitude and communication (todta ge ppoveiv Kai yevéo8or pavepods,\n16.24) of the Antiochene councillors. Equally, Ammianus writes that Julian’s measures\nseemed ‘superfluous’ (superfluum) and ill-timed, and focuses much more on the conflict\nbetween the emperor’s personality and the inhabitants of Antioch than on the scarcity 3°\n\nWhat, then, happened, and where did the communication between Julian and Antioch\ngo wrong? On Julian’s first arrival in the city, the people, gathered in the theatre for the\nadventus ceremony, shouted ‘everything plentiful; everything dear’3! Given what was\nsaid above about ritualized communication, we should read these shouts not as an\nincrimination of Julian (as he had not yet been present in the city), but rather as an\nattempt to draw his attention to the shortage: the people were hoping that the presence\nof the emperor would trigger a solution for the scarcity. Yet instead of responding\ndirectly to the people in the theatre as they probably expected, Julian decided to meet in\nprivate with the city’s leading citizens on the next day.3? After having initially not\nresponded at all in public, Julian did not follow up the issue over the next three months,\nand the scarcity got worse. As the people did not get out of their acclamations what\nthey hoped for, the popular mood may have started turning sour. Only in October 362\ndid Julian finally take measures with an edict setting maximum prices: Ammianus\n(popularitatis amore) and the fifth-century church historians Socrates (to mpoodv te\n\n2” AL H.M. As a result, it became\neven harder for the people to voice grievances to an emperor who in all likelihood came\nto be seen as a princeps clausus.*4\n\nIV THE MISOPOGON: SELF-PRESENTATION AND THE CONTROL OF INTERPRETATION\n\nJulian’s reaction to the crisis of communication came in the form of a text that was, in all\nprobability, widely circulated. Taking the insults of the Antiochenes as its starting point,\nthe Micoxiyov 6 Kai ’AvrnoyiKdg presents itself, at first sight, as a dialogue between\nemperor and city.45 In view of the preceding crisis of communication, this format is\nhighly significant, as it shows Julian finally able, and willing, to engage in dialogue. In\nreality, however, the Misopogon offers but an illusion of a dialogue.\n\nOn the one hand, a real dialogue was impossible because Julian left Antioch soon after\nhe published the Misopogon. In\nthe satirical environment of the text, the Antiochenes are shown to have grasped where\nthe essential differences lie between themselves and the emperor. Their mistake was,\nJulian suggests, to think that it would not be to his credit. Yet whilst there obviously\nwere ideological differences between Julian and the Antiochenes, it was, as argued\nabove, in no way necessary that they should lead to the falling out of Julian and\nAntioch: Christian emperors had visited largely pagan cities before without apparent\nproblems, and Julian’s stay in Constantinople does not seem to have been problematic.\nInitially, the people of Antioch were favourably disposed towards Julian, and if,\nprogressively, relations did break down, this may have been less because of Julian’s\npolicies than because he was perceived as not responding to the people. It is, then,\nJulian who consciously constructs a moral and ideological contrast to absolve himself of\nall blame for the crisis of communication that ensued and to counteract the character\nassassination of the lampoons.\n\nThe result of all this is a highly satirical text: ostensibly engaged in self-criticism and\npraise of Antioch, Julian manages to do exactly the opposite. In a recent paper on acclamations, public shouts of approval or dis-\ncontent, Hans-Ulrich Wiemer sums up their role as follows: “The main impe-\ntus for the increase and expansion of acclamations in all areas of public life was\nundoubtedly the intention of the late antique emperor to have as many people\nas possible participate in as many ceremonies as possible, which guaranteed\nhim again and again the necessary and desired legitimacy.”® This statement\nbetrays two assumptions, neither of which can be maintained: first, that all\nacclamations are ultimately aimed at the emperor, albeit via his subordinates;\nand secondly, that they are basically staged expressions of support. In fact, ac-\nclamations are a widespread phenomenon in Late Antiquity and, for example,\nextremely important in the church as well, where one cannot automatically\nassume a focus on the emperor. They also turn up in local contexts, concerned\nwith local issues, in which, again, loyalty to the emperor is hardly an issue.’\nWiemer’s reduction of acclamations to mere exercises in loyalty to the emperor\nhardly makes sense of these faces of the phenomenon. He also is mistaken, in\nmy opinion, in reducing acclamations to staged messages of loyalty. In fact, no\nformal distinction can be drawn between shouts of support and insults: both\nwere voiced in similar ways and identical contexts. As a con-\nsequence, the emperor often needed to improvise and react to unforeseen\ncircumstances. The unattractive prospect of defeat\nwas not the only source of risk: public ceremonies were occasions when people\ncould make demands through petitions or acclamations, or express their dis-\npleasure through insults. The emperor had to know how to deal with these,\nwithout losing face or causing a riot. The political capital offered by ceremonies\nwas not simply waiting to be pocketed by the emperor: it had to be gained\nthrough a successful performance. Then, largely\nunder Pope Simplicius (468-83), we can trace the search for a new relationship\nthat Rome saw as likely to compensate for these problems. The idea was to del-\negate to the bishop of Constantinople a role as the apostolic see’s representative\nfor ecclesiastical matters in the eastern empire. This function was poorly\n\n \n\ndefined and was not accompanied by a corresponding reevaluation of hierar-\nchy, jurisdictions, and protocol for the Constantinopolitan church. It therefore\nonly briefly satisfied the archbishop of Constantinople, Acacius (471-90), who\nwas keen to have his see’s influence buttressed by impressive titulature.\n\nThe Acacian schism opened with the solemn condemnation pronounced by\nPope Felix (484), but also laid bare Rome’s failings in effective communica-\ntion.’ There is no doubt that the modus vivendi wisely maintained with the\nOstrogothic king of Italy Theodoric’ permitted Pope Gelasius (492-96) to\ngive up nothing and, moreover, to reinforce a discourse that conferred on his\n\n \n\n \n\n \n\n \n\n \n\nsee and no other an ecclesiastical ministry of universal scope. In principle the\nimperial partner would have to agree and cooperate to make this model func-\ntion optimally.® But the reality of the exchange with the court of Constantino-\nple seems very far from this. Except for a brief glimpse under Pope Anastasius\n(496-98), no real opportunity for cooperation appeared until after the death in\nJuly 518 of the emperor of the same name. Acacius had in all likelihood already\nassumed the title of patriarch, and added to it the term “ecumenical.” This claim,\ndenounced firmly if obliquely by Pope Felix, reappears in a series of eastern\nletters composed on the initiative of Bishop John or addressed to him.” It may\n\n \n\nbe, therefore, that Epiphanius was floating this formulation so that, if it received\n\n \n\nno opposition, it would create the idea of supreme co-direction in the name of\nthe two principles expressed (unity of the sees and a patriarchal rank that was\ndistinct but joined by the same claim to universal oversight). Unsurprisingly,\nHormisdas no more followed up this suggestion than he accepted Epiphanius\nrank of archbishop: he only noted that his colleague had reached the sacerdotal\noffice in the most happy (felicissima) Constantinople.”** There was therefore no\nchance of any transmission of the apostolic legacy to the church of a city to\n\n \n\nwhich the pope would only concede a name commemorating its founder Con-\nstantine.             "result": "APPENDIX 4 205\n\n25 March 623 (Good Friday), celebrated Easter at Nicomedia on 27 March, and\nthen proceeded at once to the east; however, it seems improbable that Heraclius\nwould have set out on Good Friday, an ill-omened day of lamentation (even if\nsomewhat alleviated in 623 by coincidence with the Feast of the Annunciation),\ninstead of waiting an extra two days to celebrate Easter in the capital as he had in\n622. A choice should be made between the years in Theophanes and CP.\n\nThe most secure date in the sequence of Persian campaigns is their conclusion\nin 628 following the death of Khusro (see CP s.a. with notes). Theophanes,\nhowever, inserts Khusro’s death one year early (a.m. 6118 = AD 626/7);\nfurthermore he provides an incorrect indiction date for the start of the\nmanoeuvres between Heraclius and the Persian general Rhazates (317. 26: 9 Oct.\nindiction 15 = 626), whereas the correct date for their decisive battle at Nineveh\nwas Saturday 12 Dec. 627: Theophanes subsequently (318.16-17) gives the day\nand date, which are accurate for 627, not 626. Once Theophanes’ error over the\nend of the campaign is corrected, then counting back campaign years in\nTheophanes’ text gives 624 as the year of Heraclius’ second campaign, recorded\nunder a.m. 6114, where Theophanes’ indiction date is again one year early\n(306.19: March indiction 11, instead of indiction 12), and was perhaps calculated\nby reference to the incorrect date at 317. 26. Thus there is good reason to distrust\nTheophanes’ chronology and indiction dates.\n\nThere may, however, be more serious problems in the order of Theophanes’\nnarrative. The Avar siege of Cpl. is correctly located in a.m. 6117, and eastern\nmilitary events associated with this (e.g. Heraclius’ tripartite division of the\narmy, 315. 11-16) are also placed in the correct year. The sources for Theophanes’\nmilitary narrative in the 620s are unknown, but included George of Pisidia whose\npoems would not have provided precise chronological indications. Theophanes\nperhaps had to create his own chronological divisions, as he did in his account of\nthe 590s Balkan campaigns, where he attempted to clarify the obscure chronology\nof Theophylact’s narrative and created spurious year divisions in the process\n(Theoph. a.m, 6085-7; cf. Whitby, ‘Chronicle Source’ 333). As a result\nTheophanes’ distribution of material between different years cannot be trusted\nwithout external corroboration. It would not be surprising if Theophanes failed\nto realize that there was a gap of a whole year after the first campaign in 622:\nconsequently he produced a garbled date for the second campaign, inventing\nincorrect indiction dates both for this and for the final campaign year.\n\nIf this argument is correct, Heraclius did not campaign against the Persians in\n623. A suitable explanation for this break would be the need to negotiate a\nbinding agreement with the Avars in the Balkans (the western threat to which\nGeorge of Pisidia alludes at the end of the first campaign, Exp. Pers. iii. 311-40);\nthe ill-fated meeting at Heracleia formed part of this process. Hence there is no\nneed to alter CP’s date for the meeting: CP gives precise detail (e.g. ‘about hour\n4',p. 712, 21), and his contemporary knowledge of the event should be allowed\nsome authority. The same solution was adopted by E. Gerland (‘Die persischen\nFeldziige des Kaisers Herakleios’, BZ iii, 1894, 330-73), and Stratos (Byzantium\n361-5, though his discussion is not entirely clear). The extremely complicated\nquestion of the Persian campaigns is currently being re-examined in detail by Dr\nJames Howard-Johnston.\n\f"

            "result": "32 Hans-Ulrich Wiemer\n\nNachdem diese Litanei beendet war, ergriff Faustus erneut das Wort. Er wies\ndarauf hin, daß das verlesene Kaisergesetz zu Protokoll genommen werde,\nund hob hervor, daß ihm die Ehre zugefallen sei, das Gesetzbuch dem Senat\nvorzustellen. Hierauf folgten insgesamt 39 Hochrufe auf den Redner. Zum\nAbschluß legte Faustus den Senatoren dar, wie die Verbreitung des „Codex\nTheodosianus‘ vorzugehen habe. Nach weiteren 41 Hochrufen auf den Präto-\nrianerpräfekten und Konsuln war die Sitzung beendet.\n\nBemerkenswert ist hier weniger die Tatsache, daß der Senat der Publika-\ntion eines kaiserlichen Gesetzbuches ohne Diskussion zustimmte — die Zei-\nten, in denen der Senat die Geschicke der res publica bestimmt hatte, lagen\nim Jahre 438 schon fast ein halbes Jahrtausend zurück. Bemerkenswert ist\nvielmehr die Prozedur, mit der der Senat seine Zustimmung zum Ausdruck\nbrachte. Schon ihre bloße Länge ist erstaunlich: Die Gesamtzahl der zwi-\nschen acht und achtundzwanzig Mal wiederholten Akklamationen beläuft\nsich auf 820. Einmal angenommen, daß die Senatoren im Durchschnitt fünf\nSekunden pro Akklamation benötigten, müssen ihre Ausrufe über eine Stun-\nde in Anspruch genommen haben. Mommsen bereitete diese Vorstellung so\ngroßes Unbehagen, daß er die Akklamationen als individuelle Meinungs-\näußerungen (sententiae) deuten und die Iterationsziffern auf die Zahl der zu-\nstimmenden Senatoren beziehen wollte.' Diese Deutung ist indessen, wie\nOtto Hirschfeld bald darauf zeigen konnte,'? völlig unhaltbar, da zahlreiche\nParallelen, insbesondere, aber nicht nur in kirchlichen Protokollen,\" jeden Ge-\ndanken an eine Art von Stimmenzählung ausschließen.\n\n’6 Theodor MOMMSEN, Römisches Staatsrecht, Bd. Das eine Extrem markiert ein Dialog zwischen Kaiser Justi-\nnian und der „Zirkuspartei“ der Grünen, der im Hippodrom geführt wurde;\nsein historischer Kontext ist leider nicht sicher zu bestimmen.® Das von dem\nChronisten Theophanes überlieferte Protokoll” hält fest, daß die „Grünen“\nzunächst die beiden geläufigen Kaiserakklamationen „Zahlreich die Jahre!“\n(Emm xoAAd) und „Du mögest siegen!“ (toü Bikag) ausriefen, um dann\nBeschwerde gegen einen kaiserlichen Funktionär namens Kalopodios” zu\nführen. Phänomenologie der spätrömischen Akklamationen\n\nMit Hilfe der vorgestellten und anderer Texte läßt sich ein differenziertes\nBild von der Form, Verbreitung und Verwendung der Akklamationen zeich-\nnen. Blicken wir zunächst auf die Form, so zeigt sich, daß die Akklamationen\nauf den Kaiser und seine Funktionäre einen ausgesprochen formelhaften\nCharakter tragen. Dies gilt sowohl für die lateinischen als auch für die grie-\nchischen Akklamationen, auch wenn es sich bei letzteren aufgrund der un-\ngleich größeren Quellenmenge noch besser erkennen läßt. Ausrufe wie etwa\n„Zahlreich die Jahre des so und so“ (noAAd Ta Eun/multos annos), „Gott möge\ndich bewahren“ (6 @eösg oe guAdkeudeus te server), „Er/sieles siegt/Du mögest\nsiegen“ (viküd(g)/ru vincas), „Dem so und so Leben!“ (Lwrj/vita) und „Er\nist/du bist würdig“ (A&Log/dignus) begegnen in diesem Zusammenhang immer\nwieder.® Viele dieser Akklamationen sind in beiden Sprachen analog gebildet;\ndie im Kaiserzeremoniell besonders häufige Siegesakklamation wird auch im\ngriechischen Bereich häufig in der lateinischen Form ausgebracht.?” Eben\nweil diese Formeln so geläufig waren, konnten Schmährufe auf hohe Funk-\ntionäre durch Inversion der gängigen Lobpreisungen und Segenswünsche ge-\nbildet werden.®® Insofern kann man durchaus von einer relativ einheitlichen,\nreichsweiten Formelsprache sprechen. Diese Einheitlichkeit ist ohne Zweifel\ndem steuernden Einfluß des Kaisertumes geschuldet; daß die Reihenfolge, in\ndenen Herrschern akklamiert wurde, offiziell festgelegt war, ist sogar aus-\ndrücklich überliefert. Viel weniger stereotyp, mitunter sogar singulär sind\nhingegen die Akklamationen, die konkrete Wünsche und Beschwerden zum\nAusdruck bringen; sie wurden offenkundig jeweils ad hoc gebildet.\n\n% Reiches Material bei PETERSON (wie Anm. 9), S. 152-183; Theodor KLAUSER, in: RACI\n(1950), Sp. 216-230 s. v.             "result": "Akklamationen im spätrömischen Reich 57\n\nDie Akten der Arvalbrüder, eines senatorischen Priesterkollegiums, ver-\nzeichnen etwa für das Jahr 213 eine Serie von 15 Akklamationen auf Kaiser\nCaracalla.'? Zunächst einmal ist fest-\nzustellen, daß in der Spätantike neue Gruppierungen als Akklamanten des\nKaisers bezeugt sind. Bischöfe und Mönche ließen ihre Stimmen vor Kon-\nstantin nur im innerkirchlichen Bereich ertönen, die „Grünen“ und die „Blau-\nen“ nahmen erst im 5. Jahrhundert eine feste Rolle im Kaiserzeremoniell ein.\nBedeutsam erscheint weiterhin, daß Akklamationen im spätrömischen Reich\nfast immer auf den Kaiser bezogen waren, auch und gerade dann, wenn er\nnicht anwesend war. Neu ist auch, daß damit regelmäßig das formelhafte Lob\nfür die Inhaber der höchsten Ämter verbunden ist. In der früheren Kaiserzeit\nrichten sich Akklamationen in der Regel, vom Kaiserkult einmal abgesehen,\nan ein persönlich anwesendes Gegenüber, sei es der Kaiser oder sein Statt-\nhalter. Im spätrömischen Reich dagegen wenden sie sich in der Regel an Ab-\nwesende, an den Kaiser und seine höchsten Funktionäre.\n\nEin klarer, wenngleich natürlich nicht völlig unvorbereiteter Bruch ist\nschließlich auch darin zu sehen, daß den Akklamationen im spätrömischen\nReich von kirchlichen und staatlichen Instanzen große Aufmerksamkeit ge-\nschenkt wurde.             "result": "Akklamationen im spätrömischen Reich 65\n\nlischen Forderungen der zentralen Behörden seine Grenze.'* Proteste, die\nsich gegen Steuerforderungen richteten, verhallten in der Regel ungehört oder\nwurden gewaltsam unterdrückt. Der antiochenische Steueraufstand des Jah-\nres 387 etwa begann mit Akklamationen und endete mit Verhaftungen und\nTodesurteilen.'® Immerhin bleibt festzuhalten, daß Akklamationen in der\nSpätantike das einzige Medium darstellten, in welchem sich breite Kreise bei\nbestimmten Anlässen überhaupt zu politischen Fragen äußern durften.\n\nEine letzte Überlegung soll der Frage gelten, wie der Funktionswandel der\nAkklamationen mit der Entwicklung der hellenistisch-römischen Stadt zu-\nsammenhängt. In der Spätantike war den Städten als Organ politischer Wil-\nlensbildung nur noch der Stadtrat verblieben, dessen Mitglieder von der\nkaiserlichen Verwaltung für das ordentliche Funktionieren der Stadtverwal-\ntung verantwortlich gemacht wurden. Indem nun die kaiserliche Verwaltung\nAkklamationen als legitime Willensäußerungen des Volkes anerkannte, ent-\nzog sie den Stadträten das Monopol auf die politische Vertretung der Stadt\ngegenüber dem Kaiser und beeinträchtigte damit das Ansehen und den Ein-\nfluß dieser ohnehin bereits geschwächten Institution: Mit der Kontrolle über\ndie Kanäle politischer Kommunikation büßten die Ratsherren unweigerlich\ndie letzten Reste an Akzeptanz und Prestige ein, auf denen ihre Rolle als po-\nlitische Führungsschicht der Stadt einmal beruht hatte. Zugleich stärkte die\nAufwertung der Akklamationen den Einfluß von Gruppierungen, die das\nRecht, im Namen der Stadt zu sprechen, nicht mehr von einem politischen\nAuftrag ableiten konnten und woliten. Wer immer in der Lage war, Akklama-\ntionen zu organisieren, hatte die Möglichkeit, seine Anliegen als diejenigen\nder Gesamtheit auszugeben, seien es nun Bischöfe, Mönche, Inhaber hoher\n\n4# Immerhin schrieb der proconsul Asiae Phlegetius im späten 5. oder frühen 6.
